column4: statistician]]. As of 2017, she is Distinguished Professor of Statistics at [[Queensland University of Technology]] in the Science and Engineering Faculty.<ref name=profile/><ref name=praise/>

column1: She earned BA (Hons I) and PhD degrees in Mathematics, majoring in Statistics and Computing, from the [[University of New England (Australia)
column2: University of New England]] (Armidale, New South Wales, Australia) in 1985 and 1989, respectively.<ref name=profile/>  She is the Director of the Bayesian Research and Applications Group (BRAG). This group is part of the Australian Research Council (ARC) Centre of Excellence for Mathematical and Statistical Frontiers (ACEMS) of Big Data, Big Models, New Insights.<ref name=bigdata/>

column1: She has co-authored three books and edited two, and has written 27 book chapters and approximately 250 journal articles.<ref name=brag/><ref name=google/> Her research cuts across a broad spectrum of statistical practice. She is primarily known for her work in [[Bayesian statistics]] and [[meta-analysis]], and has worked in applications of statistics in [[medicine]] and [[environmental science]].<ref name=dp/> In 2016, she was the first woman to be awarded the Statistical Society of Australia's [[Pitman Medal]], which recognises outstanding achievement in the statistics discipline.<ref name=praise/> She talks about new challenges for statisticians in a YouTube video.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Professor Kerrie Mengersen Science Week 2015 Lecture at QUT
column4: last=ACEMS - ARC Centre of Excellence for Mathematical & Statistical Frontiers
column9: archivedate=10 February 2018}}</ref> She has contributed to Australian [[biosecurity]] efforts.<ref>{{cite web

column4: title=Professor Kerrie Mengersen with a panoramic camera that is helping to build virtual habitats.

column2: population = 2,925<ref name=oia>[http://www.ok.gov/oiac/documents/2011.FINAL.WEB.pdf 2011 Oklahoma Indian Nations Pocket Pictorial Directory.] {{webarchive
column4: date=2012-05-12 }} ''Oklahoma Indian Affairs Commission.'' 2011: 26. Retrieved 24 Jan 2012.</ref>

column1: The '''Peoria''' (or Peouaroua) are a [[Native Americans of the United States
column2: Native American]] people. Today they are enrolled in the [[Federally recognized tribes
column3: federally recognized]] '''Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma.''' Historically, they were part of the [[Illinois Confederation]].

column1: Traditionally, the Peoria spoke a dialect of the [[Miami-Illinois language]]. The name \"Peoria\" derives from their [[endonym
column2: autonym]] or name for themselves in the Illinois language, ''peewaareewa'' (modern pronunciation ''peewaalia''). Originally it meant, \"Comes carrying a pack on his back.\"<ref>[http://www.accessgenealogy.com/native/tribes/illinois/peoriahist.htm Peoria Indian Tribal History]. ''Access Genealogy: Indian Tribal Records.'' 2009 (retrieved 8 Feb 2009)</ref> There are no known native speakers of the Peoria language.<ref>Anderton, Alice, PhD. [http://ahalenia.com/iws/status.html \"Status of Indian Languages in Oklahoma\"], ''Intertribal Wordpath Society.'' 2009 (retrieved 8 Feb 2009)</ref> Along with the  Miami language, a smaller number of the Peoria tribe of Oklahoma once spoke Cahokia, Moingwea, and Tamaroa.

column1: The Peoria Tribe of Oklahoma is headquartered in [[Miami, Oklahoma]], and their tribal jurisdictional area is in [[Ottawa County, Oklahoma
column2: Ottawa County]]. Of the 2,925 enrolled tribal members, only 777 live within the state of Oklahoma. Craig Harper is the tribe's elected Chief, currently serving a four-year term.<ref name=oia/>

column1: The Peoria issue their own [[tribal vehicle tags]] and operate their own housing authority. The tribe owns one casino<ref name=oia/> and the Peoria Ridge Golf Course. The estimated annual economic impact of the tribe is $60 million.<ref name=\"oia\"/> Tribal businesses, the Peoria Gaming Center, Buffalo Run Casino and Hotel, and Joe's Outback are all located in Miami, Oklahoma.<ref>[http://500nations.com/Oklahoma_Casinos_Tribes.asp Oklahoma Indian Casinos: Casinos by Tribes.] ''500 Nations.'' 2009 (retrieved 8 Feb 2009)</ref>

column4: Peoria moccasins, ca. 1860, collection of [[Oklahoma History Center]]]]

column2: Algonquian]]-speaking people, whose ancestors came from what is now [[Illinois]], [[Michigan]], [[Missouri]], and [[Ohio]].<ref name=\"ptio\">[http://www.peoriatribe.com/history.php History.] {{webarchive
column4: date=2009-03-07 }} ''Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma.'' 2007 (retrieved 8 Feb 2009)</ref> Once thought to be descendants of the [[Cahokia]] [[Mississippian culture]] of [[Moundbuilders]], they are now believed to be related to Algonquian-speaking peoples of the Great Lakes and East Coast.<ref name=\"ohs\">Vaugh-Roberson, Glen. [http://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entry=PE013 Peoria.] ''Oklahoma Historical Society's Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History & Culture.'' 2009 (retrieved 8 Feb 2009)</ref> The Peoria were one of the many [[Illinois]] tribes encountered by the explorers, Father [[Jacques Marquette]] and [[Louis Jolliet]]. French [[Jesuit]] [[missionaries]] converted tribal members to [[Roman Catholicism]].<ref name=\"ohs\"/>  Father [[Jacques Gravier]], superior of the Illinois mission, compiled the most extensive [[dictionary]] of Kaskaskia [[Illinois (language)
column5: Illinois]]-French terms, nearly 600 pages and 20,000 entries.<ref>[http://ijl.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pdf_extract/17/3/325  \"Review\" of Carl Masthay, ''Kaskaskia Illinois-to-French Dictionary''], Saint Louis: Carl Masthay, 2002, ''International Journal of Lexicography'', 17(3):325–327, accessed 1 Mar 2010</ref>

column1: The Peoria migrated southwest into [[Missouri Territory]] after 1763.<ref name=\"ohs\"/> In 1818, the Treaty of Edwardsville included the cession of Peoria lands in Illinois to the United States.<ref>[http://www.museum.state.il.us/muslink/nat_amer/post/htmls/popups/timeline.html Illinois Indian History Timeline], Illinois State Museum</ref> By the 1832 Treaty of Lewisville, they ceded [[Missouri]] lands in exchange for land in [[Kansas]], near the [[Osage River]].<ref name=\"ohs\"/>

Introduced [[infectious disease]]s and intertribal wars drastically reduced the tribe's numbers.  In 1849, members of the [[Kaskaskia]], Peoria, [[Piankeshaw]], and [[Wea]] tribes formed a confederacy under the Peoria name.  The confederation also included the last members and descendants of the [[Cahokia]], [[Moingwena]], [[Michigamea]] and [[Tamaroa (tribe)
column2: Tamaroa]] tribes, who had become a part of the Peoria many year before, as well as the [[Pepikokia]], who had joined the Wea and Piankashaw in the later part of the 18th Century.<ref name=\"Rootsweb\">[http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~itquapaw/illinois/illinois.html Simpson, Linda. \"The Tribes of the Illinois Confederacy.\" May 6, 2006.] Accessed November 27, 2016.</ref>  In 1851, an Indian agent reported that the Peoria and the Kaskaskia, along with their allies, had intermarried among themselves and among white people to such an extent that they had practically lost their identities. An 1854 treaty recognized this as a factual union and called these groups the '''Confederated Peoria'''. The treaty also provided for opening the Peoria-Kaskaskia and the Wea-Piankashaw reserves to settlement by non-Indians.<ref name=\"Rootsweb\"/>

Civil War]], most of the confederated tribe signed the 1867 Omnibus Treaty.<ref name=\"ptio\"/> By this means, the US federally government purchased land from the [[Quapaw]] tribe and relocated the majority of the Peoria tribe onto a {{convert
column5: km2}} reservation in [[Indian Territory]],  part of present-day [[Ottawa County, Oklahoma]].<ref name=\"ohs\"/><ref name=\"Rootsweb\"/>{{efn
column6: In 1873, only 55 members of the Confederated Peoria chose to become citizens of Kansas so that they could remain on their own land in that state.<ref name=\"Rootsweb\"/>}}  Congress enacted a law to unite the Miami tribe of Kansas with the Confederated Peoria. The Peoria and Miami lands were allotted to the enrolled members in 1893. In 1907, any surplus land was turned over to Ottawa County.<ref name=\"Rootsweb\"/>

column1: Under the [[Dawes Act]] and [[Curtis Act of 1898]], the US government attempted to make individual allotments of land to heads of families, to allow separate ownership and cultivation of land, and break up the common landholdings of the tribes.  It was part of an effort to have the tribes [[Americanization (of Native Americans)
column2: assimilate]] to European-American ways.  At the same time, they forced tribal governments to dismantle. In 1939, after passage of the [[Oklahoma Indian Welfare Act]], the tribe reorganized and re-established its historical form of council government.<ref name=\"ptio\"/>

column1: During the 1950s, the US government pursued a policy of [[Indian termination policy
column2: Indian termination]] to end its special relationship with tribes.  It dissolved the Peoria tribal government, which lost federal recognition in 1959.  Tribal members objected and began the process to regain federal recognition, which they achieved in 1978.<ref name=\"ohs\"/> The Miami tribe never lost its Federal recognition.<ref name=\"Rootsweb\"/>

column1: The descendants of the [[Piankeshaw]], [[Kaskaskia]], and [[Wea]], all members of the [[Illinois Confederacy]], are also enrolled in the Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma.<ref>House, Office of the Law Revision Counsel. [https://books.google.com/books?id=T57ZGCu24t4C&lpg=PA986&ots=nkI-w11NKJ&dq=Kaskaskia%20enrolled%20tribe%20-college&pg=PA986#v=onepage&q&f=false ''United States Code 2006, Volume 15''.] §1224, page 986</ref>
*The city of [[Peoria, Illinois]], and the surrounding [[Peoria County, Illinois
column2: Peoria County]] are named after the tribe which lived in that area.

column1: *The [[Peoria War]] occurred in this area but is named for the town, as the tribe had already left for Missouri before this conflict occurred.
*[[Peoria, Oklahoma]], and [[Paola, Kansas]], are named directly for the tribe.

column2: other places named Peoria]] and U.S. Navy ships were named after the town in Illinois.

column1: *[[Ruthe Blalock Jones]] (b. 1939), Delaware-Shawnee-Peoria artist and educator
*[[Charles Edwin Dagenett]] (1873-1941), founder and leader of the [[Society of American Indians]]
*[http://www.peoriatribe.com Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma], official website
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930034607/http://www.usgennet.org/usa/mo/county/stlouis/native/1stcontact.htm Tribes of the Illinois/Missouri Region at First Contact (1673)]

*[http://virtual.parkland.edu/lstelle1/len/center_for_social_research/inoca_ethnohistory_project/inoca_ethnohistory.htm Inoca Ethnohistory Project: Eye Witness Descriptions of the Contact Generation, 1667–1700]
* [https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/beta/partner/peoria-historical-society Peoria Historical Society at Google Cultural Institute]

→‎Grin Low:Cleanup andtypo fixing,typo(s) fixed: commisioned → commissioned,safe,Iridescent,"{{short description
column2: History of the lime industry in Buxton, Derbyshire}}

column1: The '''Buxton lime industry''' has been important for the development of the town of [[Buxton]] in [[Derbyshire]], England, and it has shaped the landscape around the town.

The [[White Peak]] area of the [[Peak District]] is named after the limestone plateau landscape of the 'Derbyshire Dome'. This limestone outcrop is surrounded by a horseshoe-shaped formation of younger [[Sandstone
column4: shales]]. Buxton is at the western edge of the limestone region. The layers of [[Carboniferous Limestone
column5: carboniferous limestone]] were deposited in a warm shallow sea in the [[Viséan
column6: Brigantian]] stage of the [[Carboniferous]] period (around 330 million years ago). These deposits were compressed into rocks which over time were uplifted and folded into a dome. Erosion of the younger sandstones exposed the limestone [[Stratum

column1: Limestone has been quarried as building stone in the Buxton area for centuries.

column2: quicklime]]) is produced easily by heating limestone and it has been used for thousands of years. [[Lime mortar]] (a mix of lime, sand and water) has been used since ancient times for fixing together the stone blocks of buildings. Lime became used as a soil improver in agriculture since the late [[Middle Ages]]. Before electric lights, lime was burnt to light theatrical shows, putting the stage performers 'in the limelight'. Traditional round 'pudding pie' [[Lime kiln
column3: lime kilns]] were built around Buxton to burn limestone that was layered with wood, coal or coke. The lime powder was drawn from the bottom of the kiln, after it had burnt for 3 to 5 days and then cooled for a further 2 days. The process generated huge quantities of burnt waste material, taking 3 tonnes of limestone and 3 tonnes of coal to make 1 tonne of lime powder.<ref name=\":2\" />

column4: Remains of a lime kiln at Grin Low]]

column1: Grin Low was the main location in Buxton for the early lime industry. It was an extensive area of limestone quarrying and was licensed for lime burning from 1662 by the [[William Cavendish, 1st Duke of Devonshire
column2: 1st Duke Of Devonshire]]. Demand for lime grew dramatically during the [[Industrial Revolution]]. There are widespread remains of over 100 large lime kilns, built of earth and rock, which date from the 17th–19th centuries. The land is also covered in spoil heaps of waste material. Coal came from local collieries at [[Axe Edge Moor
column3: Axe Edge]] and Goyts Moss. In 1820 the [[William Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire
column4: 6th Duke of Devonshire]] commissioned the 'Grin Plantation' (now the wooded Buxton Country Park) to shield the scarred lime-burning landscape from visitors to the spa town of Buxton. In the 1850s lime production at Grin Low moved to a new large quarry on the south side of the hill (which was operated until its closure in 1952). In 1890 Grin Low produced 90,000 tonnes of lime.<ref name=\":2\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=Grin Low Lime Kilns, Buxton (HER No.2896)

column1: Grin Low Wood is a designated [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSI).<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Poole’s Cavern and Grin Low Wood

column1: Lime burning had also taken place at [[Dove Holes]] since 1650. The opening of the [[Cromford and High Peak Railway]] in 1831 generated expansion of quarrying around Buxton, with 4 new quarries: [[Harpur Hill Quarry]] in 1835, Perseverance in 1847, and Holderness and Bold Venture in 1857 at Dove Holes.
[[File:Miller's Dale - Monsal Trail view of Lime Kilns - geograph.org.uk - 945731.jpg
column3: Victorian lime kilns on the Midland line to Buxton]]

column1: In 1861 Belgian chemist [[Ernest Solvay]] developed the [[Solvay process]] (also called the ammonia-soda process) for the production of [[Sodium carbonate
column2: soda ash]] (sodium carbonate) from salt brine and limestone. Soda ash (or washing soda) was used for producing soaps, for dying textiles and for making glass.

column1: The [[Brunner Mond]] company was formed in 1873 by [[Sir John Brunner, 1st Baronet
column2: John Brunner]] and [[Ludwig Mond]]. In 1874 they started using the Solvay process to make soda ash at [[Winnington]] works in [[Northwich]], from the large local salt deposits and with limestone from Derbyshire. The soda ash was needed for the [[Lancashire]] cotton industry and for glass manufacture in [[St Helens, Merseyside
column5: title=Brunner, Mond and Co – Graces Guide
column9: title=ALKALIS FOR THE ST HELENS GLASSMAKER THROUGH THE AGES

column1: [[File:Limestone train from Tunstead to ICI Winnington 1964.jpg
column4: '''Limestone train from Tunstead to ICI Winnington, 1964''']]

column1: The arrival of the main railway lines from [[Manchester]] and [[London]] to Buxton in the 1860s prompted the opening of many further quarries: Victory in 1863, Ashwood Dale in 1864, Great Rocks in 1869, Peak Dale in 1877, Oldham Lime in 1878, East Buxton in 1880, Hindlow in 1882 and Buxton Central in 1885.<ref name=\":2\" />

Buxton Lime Firms (BLF) was formed by 13 competing quarry owners in 1891. BLF controlled the price of stone and lime from its 17 initial quarries. BLF owned over 1500 acres of land with about 100 lime kilns and 3 collieries. It produced 360,000 tons of limestone and 280,000 tons of lime per year. Larger, more advanced kilns were now in use and firebricks were introduced into kilns from 1907. By 1915 BLF had developed or acquired an additional 9 quarries including the opening of: Small Dale in 1891, Dowlow in 1898, Buxton South in 1900, Topley Pike in 1907, Brierlow in 1907, Cowdale in 1908. BLF supplied increasing quantities of lime to Brunner Mond until Brunner Mond acquired BLF in 1919, when Beelow quarry was also opened.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column7: title=British Lime Industries (formerly I.C.I. Lime Division)

column4: ICI Lime Division HQ building at the old Royal Hotel]]

column1: In 1926 [[Imperial Chemical Industries]] (ICI) was formed through the merger of Brunner Mond, [[Nobel Industries (Scotland)
column2: Nobel Industries]], [[United Alkali Company]] and [[British Dyestuffs Corporation]]. Buxton was the headquarters for I.C.I. Lime Division until the 1970s, with its headquarters in the old Royal Hotel building on Spring Gardens.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: Hillhead quarry was opened in 1927 followed by Hindlow Lane in 1928 (which was expanded with seven new kilns in 1930–31). Development of the current works at Tunstead quarry did not commence until 1929, following the expiry of leases on various other quarries in 1922.
During [[World War II]], open-topped kilns were decommissioned due to strict blackout regulations for air raids and many quarries closed.<ref name=\":1\" />

Modern quarrying is a high-technology industry using advanced machinery, supplying concrete and cement to the construction industry. Several active [[limestone]] [[quarries]] are still located close to Buxton,<ref>[http://maps.google.co.uk/?ie=UTF8&ll=53.253301,-1.883125&spn=0.113177,0.362206&t=h&z=12 Quarries visible as large white areas in satellite image], ''[[Google Maps]]'', September 2010</ref> including the \"[[Tunstead Quarry
column3: Tarmac]] in [[Great Rocks Dale]] and the largest producer of high-purity industrial limestone in Europe.<ref>[http://www.bgs.ac.uk/foundation-web/Tunstead.html Superquarries: Tunstead] {{webarchive
column5: date=6 September 2013}}, [[British Geological Survey]] website, September 2010</ref> Tarmac also operates the Hindlow Quarry at Sterndale Moor. Breedon's Dowlow Quarry is also at Sterndale Moor. The quarrying sector also provides local employment in limestone processing<ref>[http://www.tarmac.co.uk/products_and_services/buxton_lime.aspx \"Buxton Lime\"] {{webarchive
column8: Tarmac company website]], September 2010</ref> and distribution.<ref>Hailstone, Laura. [http://www.commercialmotor.com/latest-news/lomas-distribution-consolidates-sites-with-new-depot \"Lomas Distribution consolidates sites with new depot\"] {{webarchive
column10: date=7 August 2012}}, Commercialmotor.com, 1 July 2008, accessed 29 August 2012</ref> Goods railway lines run between these quarries and Buxton, where they join the main railway network. The Topley Pike Quarry is now owned and run by Aggregate Industries.

column2: History of the lime industry in Buxton, Derbyshire}}

column1: The '''Buxton lime industry''' has been important for the development of the town of [[Buxton]] in [[Derbyshire]], England, and it has shaped the landscape around the town.

The [[White Peak]] area of the [[Peak District]] is named after the limestone plateau landscape of the 'Derbyshire Dome'. This limestone outcrop is surrounded by a horseshoe-shaped formation of younger [[Sandstone
column4: shales]]. Buxton is at the western edge of the limestone region. The layers of [[Carboniferous Limestone
column5: carboniferous limestone]] were deposited in a warm shallow sea in the [[Viséan
column6: Brigantian]] stage of the [[Carboniferous]] period (around 330 million years ago). These deposits were compressed into rocks which over time were uplifted and folded into a dome. Erosion of the younger sandstones exposed the limestone [[Stratum

column1: Limestone has been quarried as building stone in the Buxton area for centuries.

column2: quicklime]]) is produced easily by heating limestone and it has been used for thousands of years. [[Lime mortar]] (a mix of lime, sand and water) has been used since ancient times for fixing together the stone blocks of buildings. Lime became used as a soil improver in agriculture since the late [[Middle Ages]]. Before electric lights, lime was burnt to light theatrical shows, putting the stage performers 'in the limelight'. Traditional round 'pudding pie' [[Lime kiln
column3: lime kilns]] were built around Buxton to burn limestone that was layered with wood, coal or coke. The lime powder was drawn from the bottom of the kiln, after it had burnt for 3 to 5 days and then cooled for a further 2 days. The process generated huge quantities of burnt waste material, taking 3 tonnes of limestone and 3 tonnes of coal to make 1 tonne of lime powder.<ref name=\":2\" />

column4: Remains of a lime kiln at Grin Low]]

column1: Grin Low was the main location in Buxton for the early lime industry. It was an extensive area of limestone quarrying and was licensed for lime burning from 1662 by the [[William Cavendish, 1st Duke of Devonshire
column2: 1st Duke Of Devonshire]]. Demand for lime grew dramatically during the [[Industrial Revolution]]. There are widespread remains of over 100 large lime kilns, built of earth and rock, which date from the 17th–19th centuries. The land is also covered in spoil heaps of waste material. Coal came from local collieries at [[Axe Edge Moor
column3: Axe Edge]] and Goyts Moss. In 1820 the [[William Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire
column4: 6th Duke of Devonshire]] commisioned the 'Grin Plantation' (now the wooded Buxton Country Park) to shield the scarred lime-burning landscape from visitors to the spa town of Buxton. In the 1850s lime production at Grin Low moved to a new large quarry on the south side of the hill (which was operated until its closure in 1952). In 1890 Grin Low produced 90,000 tonnes of lime.<ref name=\":2\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=Grin Low Lime Kilns, Buxton (HER No.2896)

column1: Grin Low Wood is a designated [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSI).<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Poole’s Cavern and Grin Low Wood

column1: In film, Jones has appeared in ''[[I Love You, Man]]'' (2009), ''[[The Social Network]]'' (2010) and ''[[Celeste and Jesse Forever]]'' (2012), which she co-wrote. Jones also co-wrote the story of ''[[Toy Story 4]]'' (2019).

As a filmmaker, she directed the first episode of ''[[Hot Girls Wanted]]'', a series that focused on the sex industry. She was also executive producer of the series. In 2018, her documentary ''[[Quincy (film)
column2: Quincy]]'', about her father, [[Quincy Jones]], debuted on [[Netflix]]; it won the [[Grammy Award for Best Music Film]] in 2019.

column8: s}};<!--assuming this is the English pronunciation--> born February 10, 1980) is a [[Venezuela]]n former professional [[baseball]] [[shortstop]]. He is the half-brother of shortstop [[Maicer Izturis]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title = Izturis brothers feel no rivalry

column1: Signed by the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1996 in baseball
column2: 1996]], Izturis made his debut with Toronto in [[2001 Major League Baseball season
column3: 2001]] and was traded to the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] at the end of the season.

column1: Coming from a long tradition of Venezuelan shortstops, which includes [[Chico Carrasquel]], [[Luis Aparicio]], [[Dave Concepción]], [[Ozzie Guillén]], [[Omar Vizquel]], [[Álex González (infielder, born 1977)
column2: Álex González]] and [[Carlos Guillén]], Izturis has the defensive skills to rank in such distinguished company. After showing some hitting potential with a .269 [[batting average (baseball)
column3: average]] in his rookie season with Toronto, the Dodgers were enthusiastic to trade for him.

column1: Izturis was designated as the everyday starting shortstop from Opening Day of the [[2002 Major League Baseball season
column2: 2002 season]], and he quickly established himself in the Dodgers' infield. But he showed no patience at the plate, resulting in a decline in average and very few [[Base on balls
column3: walks]]. After two years of barely adequate hitting (though compensated by his stellar glovework), he improved markedly in 2004, when he hit .288 with 62 [[Run batted in
column4: RBI]] and 25 [[stolen base]]s in 159 games. At the end of the season, he earned his first [[Gold Glove Award
column5: Gold Glove]], the first by a Dodger shortstop since [[Maury Wills]]' back-to-back honors in [[1961 Major League Baseball season

column2: 2005]], Izturis hit .348 through June 1 and led the entire majors in [[Hit (baseball)
column3: hits]]. He was selected for the [[2005 Major League Baseball All-Star Game
column4: National League All-Star]] team, but his batting average later dipped all the way down into the .250 range. Curiously, his defense also seemed to suffer. After two trips to the [[disabled list]], Izturis underwent [[Tommy John surgery]] in his right elbow, and returned in mid-June, 2006.

column1: With the uncertainty around Izturis, the Dodgers acquired shortstop [[Rafael Furcal]] in the off-season. That move seemed to have put Izturis' future with the Dodgers in doubt. With a $13 million annual salary, Furcal did not seem a likely candidate to be benched.
At the 2006 trade deadline, Izturis was traded to the [[Chicago Cubs]] for [[Greg Maddux]] and cash considerations.
On July 19, 2007, Izturis and cash were traded to the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] for a player to be named later.

On November 16, 2007, the Pirates declined an option on Izturis, and he became a free agent. Shortly thereafter on November 30, 2007, Izturis signed a one-year, $2.85 million deal with the St. Louis Cardinals.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title = Izturis deal nudges out Eckstein

column1: On December 16, 2008, Izturis signed a two-year deal with the [[Baltimore Orioles]]<ref>{{cite web

column2: 2009]], he led all starting shortstops in [[range factor]], at 4.89.<ref>[http://espn.go.com/mlb/stats/fielding/_/position/ss/sort/rangeFactor/order/true \"MLB Player Fielding Stats – As ss – 2009\"] ''ESPN'', accessed October 6, 2009</ref>

column1: On December 10, 2010, Izturis re-signed with the [[Baltimore Orioles]] to a 1-year contract.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Orioles, SS Izturis agree to $1.5M, 1-year deal

column1: On December 21, 2011 he signed a minor league contract with the [[Milwaukee Brewers]]. He also received an invitation to spring training. On March 29, 2012, Izturis was added to the Major League 25-man roster by the Brewers.

On August 6, 2012, the [[Washington Nationals]] claimed Izturis off waivers from the Brewers. He was [[designated for assignment]] by the [[Washington Nationals]] on August 17, only 11 days after arriving in Washington. On August 20, 2012, he was granted free agency.
On January 14, 2013, the [[Cincinnati Reds]] announced that they had signed Izturis to a minor league contract with an invitation to major league spring training.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Reds sign Cesar Izturis to minor league deal
column7: accessdate=January 14, 2013}}</ref> The Reds selected the contract of Izturis on March 31.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Cesar Izturis News: The Reds purchased Izturis' contract from Triple-A Louisville on Sunday, MLB.com reports

column1: Izturis signed a minor league deal with the [[Houston Astros]] on January 14, 2014. He was released on March 24.

Izturis resides in [[Barquisimeto, Venezuela]] in the offseason with his wife Liliana and their two children; his son Cesar Daniel (born 11-11-1999) and daughter Daniella (born 7-17-2006).<ref>[http://mlb.mlb.com/team/player_career.jsp?player_id=285131 Cesar Izturis: Biography and Career Highlights] orioles.com</ref> In 2016, Cesar Daniel signed with the [[Seattle Mariners]] as an international free agent.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Mariners agree to terms with Izturis Jr

Izturis resides in [[Barquisimeto, Venezuela]] in the offseason with his wife Liliana and their two children; his son Cesar Daniel (born 11-11-1999) and daughter Daniella (born 7-17-2006).<ref>[http://mlb.mlb.com/team/player_career.jsp?player_id=285131 Cesar Izturis: Biography and Career Highlights] orioles.com</ref> In 2016, Cesar Daniel signed with the [[Seattle Mariners]] as an international free agent.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Mariners agree to terms with Izturis Jr

The '''2020–21 Temple Owls men's basketball team''' represents [[Temple University]] during the [[2020–21 NCAA Division I men's basketball season]]. The Owls, led by second-year head coach [[Aaron McKie]], play their home games at the [[Liacouras Center]] in [[Philadelphia]] as a member of the [[American Athletic Conference]].
The [[2019–20 Temple Owls men's basketball team
column2: Owls]] finished the [[2019–20 NCAA Division I men's basketball season
column3: 2019–20 season]] 14–17, 6–12 in [[2019–20 American Athletic Conference men's basketball season
column4: AAC play]] to finish in tenth place. They entered as the No. 10 seed in the [[2020 American Athletic Conference Men's Basketball Tournament
column5: AAC Tournament]], which was ultimately cancelled due to the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic

column5: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref>) is a Czech fine art creator who works with the urban environment and iconography of the city (Prague). His interventions frequently focus on contemporary social topics and regularly addresses issues surrounding [[public space]]. His identity has remained unknown to date.<ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite web
column7: title=\"Bývalý\" graffiťák EPOS 257 pro INFO.CZ: Město se musí měnit. Nedá se nad tím brečet
column11: trans-title=\"Former\" graffiti EPOS 257 for INFO.CZ: The city has to change. You can't cry over it}}</ref>

column1: Born in the 1980s in Prague, Epos 257 started his career as a writer (a person who creates graffiti - street art sub-culture jargon). Some principle characteristics of [[graffiti]] can still be traced in the artist's work. Above all, it is the invasive nature of the work, the insider's awareness of the urban landscape and the conscious movement on the edge of the law or beyond.<ref>{{Cite book
column2: title=The world atlas of street art and graffiti
column15: oclc=649799098}}</ref> Epos 257 is a graduate of the [[Academy of Arts, Architecture and Design in Prague
column16: Academy of Arts, Architecture and Design]]<ref name=\"auto\"/> and a member of the interdisciplinary group [[Ztohoven]]<ref name=\"auto\"/>

column1: Epos 257's art is characterised by examination of public space, especially the way it is used and the limits of what is and is not public.<ref name=\"auto\"/> He repeatedly challenges the creation in public with its institutional conception.<ref name=\"auto1\">{{Cite interview
column5: title=Snažím se propojit galerii s ulicí, říká Epos 257 {{!}} Aktuálně.cz
column6: website=Aktuálně.cz - Víte, co se právě děje
column9: trans-title=I'm trying to connect the gallery to the street, says Epos 257}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> He has five solo and several collective exhibitions at home and abroad to his name.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In 2009, Epos 257 anonymously placed more than thirty bales of [[hay]] around the centre of Prague, as it is done after harvesting in the countryside. However, his actions were subsequently interpreted (especially by the tabloid media) as a public threat and even associated with [[terrorism]].<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=Radio Wave}}</ref> After some time, he repeated this undertaking as part of the implementation for the [[National Theatre (Prague)
column6: National Theater]] on the Piazzetta of the [[National Theatre (Prague)
column7: National Theater]] (renamed to [[Václav Havel]] Square), albeit this time intentionally obtaining all the required official permissions<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

column1: A year later, Epos continued dealing with the boundaries of public space, even in the context of legislation. At that time, he put up a fence around space on [[Palackého náměstí (Praha)
column2: Palackeho Square]] (on which there is an exemption to the law prohibiting public gatherings without notice, and which is therefore referred to as the Czech “[[Hyde Park, London
column3: Hyde Park]]”), around an area of 50 square meters. Inside the delimited space, nothing was happening or placed other than what was outside of it. The absurd enclosure lasted 54 days on the square. After such a long time, the artist himself contacted city officials. This work was connected to the pointing out the indifference to the use of public space and the unjustifiableness of certain restrictions associated with it.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Epos 257 v Bourání: Graffiti je indikátor opuštěnosti místa, ale i svobody
column10: trans-title=Epic 257 in Demolition: Graffiti is an indicator of the abandonment of place, but also of freedom}}</ref>

column1: Epos 257 has also repeatedly devoted himself to [[billboard]]s. For example, In the Portrait project, which was realised before the Czech presidential elections in 2013, he cut out the giant faces of both the final candidates, smiling at people from their gigantic posters, and then framed them. While he left the remains of the promotional posters lacking the faces of politicians in the original place. Epos installed the framed and glazed representations opposite each other. Shortly after his election, Epos went on to place a gigantic portrait of the winner of the elections [[Miloš Zeman]] in the [[Czech National Library of Technology
column4: title=Epos 257: Umělec, který prodal zarámovanou loupež {{!}} Recenze

column1: It was mainly for his “billboard” projects that Epos 257 was repeatedly associated with breaking the law. His actions before the presidential and municipal elections also revived the debate on the ethical boundaries of artistic creation. The artist did, however, fully compensate the billboard owners for the financial damages he caused in 2013 by cutting out the heads of the presidential candidates<ref>{{Cite web
* 2019 Dýmová hora, The City of Prague Museum, Prague<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web
* 2018 Kořeny, větve, šlahouny, Trafo Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2017 Retroreflexe, Trade Fair Palace, National Gallery Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2014 Who Cares? Dancing House Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2012 I can't help myself, Trafo Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2016 The Art of Urban Interference, Gallery Apollonia, Strasbourg <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2015 Bien Urban, Public Art Festival, Besançon <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2014 Politika, Urban Space Gallery, Manchester <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2014 Nad čarou, DOX Centre for Contemporary Art, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2014 Vabanque, Czech Centre Berlin Gallery, Berlín <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2013 Cultural Hijack, Institut of Architecture and School of Architecture AA, London <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2012 Stuck on the City, Prague City Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2011 Home, Upper Space Gallery, Manchester <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2010 Urban Inventions, Urban Art Info Gallery, Berlin <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2010 Young Art Bienalle ZVON, Prague City Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2010 Metropolis, Czech Pavilon Expo 2010, Shanghai <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2008 NAMES, Street Art Festival, Trafo Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2008 Pod čarou, Hall C, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2007 Prague street art, Leica Gallery 28; Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2007 Keep it Thoro, NoD Gallery, Prague <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2005 European Street, Gallery Du Moment, Brussels <ref name=\"auto2\"/>
* 2009 ''About a Tree,'' Agarde Publishing, Prague<ref>{{Cite web

'''''Mussaurus''''' (meaning \"[[mouse]] [[lizard]]\") is a [[genus]] of [[herbivorous]] [[sauropodomorph]] [[dinosaur]] that lived in southern [[Argentina]] during the [[Late Triassic]], about 215 [[million years ago]]. It receives its name from the small size of the skeletons of juvenile and infant individuals, which were once the only known specimens of the genus. However, since ''Mussaurus'' is now known from adult specimens,<ref name=OP13>{{Cite journal
column7: title = Postcranial anatomy and phylogenetic relationships of ''Mussaurus patagonicus'' (Dinosauria, Sauropodomorpha)
column14: pmc = }}</ref> the name is something of a misnomer; adults possibly reached {{convert
column17: ft}} in length and weighed more than {{convert
column20: lb}}.<ref name=\"Otero Cuff Allen Sumner-Rooney 2019-5-20\">{{cite journal
column33: title=Ontogenetic changes in the body plan of the sauropodomorph dinosaur Mussaurus patagonicus reveal shifts of locomotor stance during growth
column35: publisher=Springer Science and Business Media LLC
column43: pmc=6527699}}</ref> ''Mussaurus'' possesses anatomical features suggesting a close, possibly transitional evolutionary relationship with true sauropods.<ref name=\"ageofdinosaursmussaurus\"/>

column1: '' were first discovered by an expedition led by [[Jose Bonaparte]] during the 1970s to the [[El Tranquilo Formation]].<ref name=\"ageofdinosaursmussaurus\">\"Mussaurus.\" In: Dodson, Peter & Britt, Brooks & Carpenter, Kenneth & Forster, Catherine A. & Gillette, David D. & Norell, Mark A. & Olshevsky, George & Parrish, J. Michael & Weishampel, David B. ''The Age of Dinosaurs''. Publications International, LTD. p. 40. {{ISBN
column2: 0-7853-0443-6}}.</ref> There the team found fossilized eggs and hatchlings, which added insight into the reproductive strategies of ''Mussaurus'' and other sauropodomorph dinosaurs.<ref name=\"ageofdinosaursmussaurus\"/> The first adult specimens of ''Mussaurus'' were described in 2013. Some of these specimens had first been described in 1980 and were originally attributed to the genus ''[[Plateosaurus]]''.<ref name=OP13/>

column1: Previous to the discovery of adult specimens of ''Mussaurus'', the [[phylogenetic]] position of this taxon was difficult to establish. Infant and juvenile fossils are known to show more [[basal (phylogenetics)
column2: basal]] traits than adult specimens of the same taxon. Furthermore, the recently discovered one subadult and three adult specimens assigned to ''Mussaurus'' are more complete than other material assigned to it. Therefore, a cladistic analysis of basal sauropodomorphs performed by Otero and Pol (2013) to test the phylogenetic relationships of ''Mussaurus'', included information only from adult specimens. The following [[cladogram]] is simplified after their analysis (relationships outside Plateosauria are not shown).<ref name=OP13/>

column3: Life restoration of an infant eating a ''[[Dicroidium]]'' fern]]

column1: Mussaurus specimens have been found in association with nests that are believed to contain multiple eggs apiece. The skeletons of ''Mussaurus'' infants were small, only six inches long excluding the tail, but a total of {{convert
column6: in}} long. This is about the size of a small lizard. Juveniles differed from adults in proportion in addition to size and mass. As is common for dinosaurs, juvenile ''Mussaurus'' had tall skulls with short snouts and large eyes.<ref name=\"ageofdinosaursmussaurus\"/>

column1: These proportions are common in many infant vertebrates and are often associated with species that provide parental care during the vulnerable early stages of life. Adults are expected to have longer snouts and necks, as typical in early [[sauropodomorph]]s.
A study published in May 2019 shows that while ''M. patagonicus'' probably walked on all four limbs (was [[quadrupedalism
column2: quadrupedal]]) during the first year of its life, changes in the relative proportions of its body during growth ([[ontogeny]]) caused its [[centre of mass]] to move backwards towards its [[pelvis]], resulting in the animal adopting a two-legged ([[bipedalism
column3: bipedal]]) stance later in life.<ref name=\"Otero Cuff Allen Sumner-Rooney 2019-5-20\"/><ref name=\"Geggel 2019\">{{cite web
column6: title=No, That Baby Dinosaur Didn't Crawl. But It Did Walk on 4 Legs As an Infant.

column7: title = El hallazgo del primer nido de dinosaurios triasicos, (Saurischia, Prosauropoda), Triasico Superior de Patagonia, Argentina [The discovery of the first nest of Triassic dinosaurs (Saurischia, Prosauropoda,) from the Upper Triassic of Patagonia, Argentina]
title = Skull anatomy of ''Mussaurus patagonicus'' (Dinosauria: Sauropodomorpha) from the Late Triassic of Patagonia

column2: released   = <!-- Commercial release date, not SoundCloud upload date -->{{start date
genre      = [[Lo-fi hip hop]]<!-- Sourced in prose -->

column1: \"'''Death Bed'''\", released in later versions as \"'''Death Bed (Coffee for Your Head)'''\"<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=\"death bed (coffee for your head) (feat. beabadoobee)\" on Spotify}}</ref> (stylized in [[Letter case#All lowercase
column4: all lowercase]]) is a song by Canadian rapper [[Powfu]], featuring Filipino-British singer-songwriter [[Beabadoobee]]. The song was initially uploaded to [[SoundCloud]] in 2019; following Powfu signing to [[Columbia Records]], the song was released on streaming services on February 8, 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Powfu Breaks Down The Meaning Of \"Death Bed\"
column12: accessdate=March 18, 2020}}</ref> The song samples the 2017 song \"Coffee\" by Beabadoobee, who is credited as a feature.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Powfu & Beabadoobee's \"Death Bed\" Picks Up Pop Radio Airplay, Reaches 50 Million Spotify Streams

column1: The song went viral on the video sharing app [[TikTok]] in early 2020.<ref name=\"Genius BG\">{{cite web
column3: title=Powfu's Viral Hit \"Death Bed\" Arrives On Streaming Services After Lengthy Sample Clearance Delay

column1: The song's commercial release was delayed by a year due to the clearance of the [[Sampling (music)
column2: sample]] of Beabadoobee's 2017 song \"Coffee\". Powfu said on [[Twitter]] in April 2019 that he had not put it on [[Spotify]] because he was \"scared [he'd] get in trouble from the sample [he] use[s] in it\", but said he \"would upload it anyway\" and told his followers to give him \"a week and a half\". It was finally released to streaming and download services in February 2020.<ref name=\"Genius BG\"/>

column1: \"'''Death Bed'''\", released in later versions as \"'''Death Bed (Coffee for Your Head)'''\"<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=\"death bed (coffee for your head) (feat. beabadoobee)\" on Spotify}}</ref> (stylized in [[Letter case#All lowercase
column4: all lowercase]]) is a song by Canadian rapper [[Powfu]], featuring Filipino-British singer-songwriter [[Beabadoobee]]. The song was initially uploaded to [[SoundCloud]] in 2019; following Powfu signing to [[Columbia Records]], the song was released on streaming services on February 8, 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Powfu Breaks Down The Meaning Of \"Death Bed\"
column12: accessdate=March 18, 2020}}</ref> The song samples the 2017 song \"Coffee\" by Beabadoobee, who is credited as a feature.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Powfu & Beabadoobee's \"Death Bed\" Picks Up Pop Radio Airplay, Reaches 50 Million Spotify Streams

column1: '''Jakub Kochanowski''' (born 17 July 1997) is a Polish [[volleyball]] player, a member of [[Poland men's national volleyball team]] and [[PGE Skra Bełchatów]], [[2018 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship
column2: 2018 World Champion]], [[2015 Boys' Youth European Volleyball Championship
column3: U19 European Champion 2015]], [[2015 FIVB Volleyball Boys' U19 World Championship
column4: U19 World Champion 2015]], [[2016 Men's U20 Volleyball European Championship
column5: U20 European Champion 2016]], [[2017 FIVB Volleyball Men's U21 World Championship

column1: On 12 April 2015, [[Poland men's national under-19 volleyball team]], including Kochanowski, won title of [[2015 Boys' Youth European Volleyball Championship
column2: U19 European Champion 2015]]. They beat in final [[Italy men's national volleyball team
column5: title =ME kadetów: Ogromny sukces reprezentacji Polski! Jest złoto!
column12: title =Poland crown fabulous campaign with gold, Italy and Turkey complete podium
column17: access-date = 9 February 2018}}</ref> He took part in [[Volleyball at the 2015 European Youth Summer Olympic Festival
column18: European Youth Olympic Festival]] with [[Poland men's national under-19 volleyball team
column19: Polish national U19 team]]. On August 1, 2015 he achieved gold medal (final match with Bulgaria 3–0). On August 23, 2015 [[Poland men's national under-19 volleyball team
column20: Poland]] achieved first title of [[2015 FIVB Volleyball Boys' U19 World Championship
column21: U19 World Champion]]. In the final his team beat hosts - Argentina (3–2).<ref>{{cite web
column23: title = History rewritten for Poland as they grab first ever Boy's U19 gold medal
column28: access-date = 9 February 2018}}</ref> On September 10, 2016 he achieved title of the [[2016 Men's U20 Volleyball European Championship
column29: 2016 CEV U20 European Champion]] after winning 7 of 7 matches in tournament and beating Ukraine U21 in the final (3–1).<ref>{{cite web
column31: title =Poland triumph with U20 European gold in Plovdiv
column36: access-date = 9 February 2018}}</ref> On July 2, 2017 [[Poland men's national under-21 volleyball team
column37: Poland U21]], including Kochanowski, achieved title of [[2017 FIVB Volleyball Men's U21 World Championship
column38: U21 World Champion 2017]] after beating Cuba U21 in the final (3–0).<ref>{{cite web
column40: title =Poland shut out Cuba to triumph with U21 World Championship gold!
column47: title =Great generation of Polish players celebrate time together with U21 world title
column52: access-date = 23 January 2018}}</ref> Kochanowski was awarded an individual award for the Most Valuable Player of the whole tournament.<ref>{{cite web
column54: title =Poland’s leader Kochanowski recognized as U21 World Champ
column59: access-date = 9 February 2018}}</ref> He was a captain of Poland U21 and led the national team to 4th title in boys' and youth's competitions. His national team won 47 matches in the row and never lost.<ref>{{cite web
column61: title =47 games without losing! I am so proud of these boys – coach Pawlik
column66: access-date = 23 January 2018}}</ref> The U21 World Champion title ended up his time in youth national teams.

column1: In April 2017 he was called up for the senior [[Poland men's national volleyball team]] for the first time, by head coach [[Ferdinando De Giorgi
column4: title =De Giorgi podał skład na Ligę Światową! Nie ma dwóch Mistrzów Świata
column9: access-date = 9 February 2018}}</ref> He joined to the team on [[2017 FIVB Volleyball World League
column10: 2017 FIVB World League]] before the first week of competition because of [[Andrzej Wrona]]'s injury.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title =Kochanowski dołączył do kadry De Giorgiego
column17: access-date = 9 February 2018}}</ref> Jakub debuted in the senior Polish national team on June 3, 2017 during the winning match with Italy (3–1).

column1: After successful season 2017/18 in [[Indykpol AZS Olsztyn]] and achieving 4th place in the league he left previous club. On May 10, 2018 he was announced as the new player of [[PGE Skra Bełchatów]].
On September 30, 2018 Poland achieved title of the [[2018 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship
column3: title=Poland triumph over Brazil to retain World title for years more years
column6: accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref>. Poland beat Brazil in the final 3-0 and defended the title from 2014.

The '''Ornate Butterflyfish''', '''Chaetodon ornatissimus''', is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish, Clown Butterfly, Coralfishes, Ornate Butterfly, Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish
column2: Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish
column3: Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler, Jennifer L., and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”, but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish, it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon, which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish
column4: Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these, they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout, and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon
column2: lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\">Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.</ref>. Juvenile ornate butterflyfish are solitary and can be found singly, living in the arms of branching corals, but form pairs during breeding <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics
column2: tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]], the [[Marquesas Islands
column3: Marquesas]], the [[Pitcairn Islands]], North to Southern [[Japan]], South to Lord Howe, and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández, Sebastián, et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut
column4: Hsu, Kui-Ching; Chen, Jeng-Ping & Shao, Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine, inshore, tropical (30°N - 30°S, 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers, R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada, Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile, benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms, unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett, M. S., Wilson, S. K., & Baird, A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology'', ''69''(5), 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing, pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however, by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish, specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish, and localized extinctions, following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al., revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growthBrooker, R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6''', 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development. Coral reef communities provide shelter, and food resources for Butterflyfish. However, the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish, as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species, which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish
column15: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores, which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)
column18: Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore, butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral, and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake, sprint, turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: * Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.

*Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki>

''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'' '''14''': 77–86. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070811042056/http://rmbr.nus.edu.sg/rbz/biblio/s14/s14rbz10_Hsu-pp77-86.pdf PDF fulltext]

However, the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish, as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species, which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish
column15: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores, which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)
column18: Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore, butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral, and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake, sprint, turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: Minor tidyups overall, nothing hurt whatsoever.,safe,Quite A Character,"{{Spanish name
'''Antoni Ramallets Simón''' (1 July 1924 – 30 July 2013) was a Spanish [[Association football
column2: footballer]] who played as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)

column1: He spent most of his career at [[FC Barcelona
column3: Zamora Trophy]] as the best goalkeeper in [[La Liga]] on five occasions and 18 total honours.<ref>[http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/noticias/20090713/53743727820/las-85-vidas-del-gato-con-alas.html Las 85 vidas del 'Gato con Alas' azulgrana (The 85 lives of the blaugrana 'Winged Cat')]; [[La Vanguardia]], 13 July 2009 {{in lang
column4: es}}</ref> He represented [[Spain national football team
column5: Spain]] in the [[1950 FIFA World Cup

column1: Ramallets managed several teams in his country in the 60s, notably winning two major trophies with [[Real Zaragoza

Born in [[Barcelona]], [[Catalonia]], Ramallets signed for [[FC Barcelona]] in 1947 at the age of 23 from [[Real Valladolid]], where he also spent his first season after being purchased, on loan. He returned to the club to play second-fiddle to [[Juan Zambudio Velasco
column2: Juan Velasco]], making his [[La Liga]] debut in a 2–1 victory over [[Sevilla FC]] on 28 November 1948. Although this was his only appearance during [[1948–49 La Liga
column3: the season]] he eventually became the starter, being an essential defensive unit as his team – then named Club de Fútbol Barcelona – went on to win six leagues and five [[Copa del Rey
column5: 1951–52]], as ''Barça'' won five major trophies, he contributed with 28 league games, being awarded his first [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy]].

column1: During the 1950s, Ramallets was a prominent member of the successful Barcelona team that also included [[Joan Segarra]], [[Marià Gonzalvo]], [[László Kubala]], [[Sándor Kocsis]], [[Evaristo de Macedo
column3: Luis Suárez]] and [[Zoltán Czibor]].<ref>[https://www.fcbarcelona.es/es/ficha/643900/1950-61-kubala-y-su-tiempo# 1950–61. Kubala y su tiempo (1950–61. Kubala and his time)]; FC Barcelona, 13 March 2018 {{in lang
column4: es}}</ref> During his spell with the club he made 538 appearances, including 288 in the domestic league; on 6 March 1962 the ''Blaugrana'' played a [[Testimonial match
column5: testimonial]] in his honour against [[Hamburger SV]], winning 5–1.<ref>[https://www.rtve.es/deportes/20130730/fallece-ramallets-mitico-portero-del-barcelona-89-anos/727721.shtml Fútbol {{!}} Obituarios – Fallece Ramallets, mítico portero del Barcelona, a los 89 años (Football {{!}} Deaths – Death of Ramallets, legendary Barcelona goalkeeper, at the age of 89)]; [[RTVE]], 30 July 2013 {{in lang
column6: es}}</ref><ref>[https://elpais.com/deportes/2013/07/30/actualidad/1375199929_294426.html Antoni Ramallets, el portero sin guantes que saltaba como un gato (Antoni Ramallets, the goalkeeper without gloves who jumped like a cat)]; [[El País]], 30 July 2013 {{in lang

column1: Ramallets coached several clubs during the following decade, including old acquaintance Valladolid. In the [[1963–64 La Liga
column2: 1963–64 campaign]] he led [[Real Zaragoza]] to the fourth place in the league, the [[1963–64 Copa del Generalísimo
column3: Spanish Cup]] and the [[1963–64 Inter-Cities Fairs Cup
column4: Inter-Cities Fairs Cup]] – a competition he had won twice as a player with Barcelona – defeating fellow league team [[Valencia CF]] in the latter.<ref>[https://www.elperiodicodearagon.com/noticias/deportes/fallece-ramallets-entrenador-real-zaragoza-epoca-magnificos_872762.html Fallece Ramallets, entrenador del Real Zaragoza en la época de los Magníficos (Death of Ramallets, manager of Real Zaragoza during the age of the Magnificent)]; [[El Periódico de Aragón]], 31 July 2013 {{in lang

column1: Ramallets played 35 games for [[Spain national football team
column2: Spain]] during 11 years, making his debut against [[Chile national football team
column3: Chile]] on 29 June 1950, during the [[1950 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil.<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/ramallets-intl.html Antonio Ramallets Simón – International Appearances] {{webarchive
column5: date=8 July 2007}}; at [[RSSSF]]</ref> During the tournament he earned the nickname ''The Cat of [[Estádio do Maracanã
column6: Maracaná]]'', helping the nation to the second group stage.<ref>[https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/mundial-futbol/gato-maracana-3294730 Ramallets, el gato de Maracaná (Ramallets, the cat of Maracaná)]; [[Sport (Spanish newspaper)

column1: Ramallets also played seven games for the unofficial [[Catalonia national football team

Ramallets died in his [[Vilafranca del Penedès]] home near Barcelona, on 31 July 2013. He was 89 years old.<ref>[http://www.mundodeportivo.com/20130730/fc-barcelona/ramallets-muerte-fallecimiento_54379004856.html Ha muerto Antoni Ramallets (Antoni Ramallets has died)] {{Webarchive
column4: es}}</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.es/deportes/futbol/20130730/abci-muere-ramallets-barcelona-201307301753.html Fallece a los 89 años Antoni Ramallets, el mítico portero del Barcelona (Antoni Ramallets, legendary Barcelona goalkeeper, dies at the age of 89)]; [[ABC (newspaper)
column6: es}}</ref><ref>[http://www.euronews.com/2013/07/31/former-spain-keeper-ramallets-dies-aged-89/ Former Spain keeper Ramallets dies aged 89]; [[Euronews]], 31 July 2013</ref>

column1: [[Category:Association football players who received a testimonial]]",Antoni Ramallets,//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antoni_Ramallets
'''Homayoun Behzadi''' (20 June 1942 – 22 January 2016) was an Iranian [[Association football
column2: footballer]] and coach. He usually played as a [[Striker (association football)

column1: He was born on 4 January 1942 in [[Khorramabad]], [[Lorestan Province]]. Behzadi first broke into the [[Shahin F.C.
column2: Shahin]] side when he was only 16 years old. He played for Shahin until 1966, when – due to financial problems – Shahin closed. He is graduated in [[Persian language]].

column1: In 1967, he changed to [[Paykan Tehran F.C.
column2: Paykan]], then he changed to [[Persepolis F.C.
column3: Persepolis]] in spring 1968. Because of a heavy injury happened in the [[1968 Asian Cup]], his contract was dissolved, and Behzadi went back to Peykan. There he won the Tehran Championship in 1970 before changing to [[Persepolis F.C.
column4: Persepolis]] in 1970. There he won the Iranian league in [[1971–72 Local League
column5: 1972]] as well as in [[1973–74 Takht Jamshid Cup

column1: In 1966 he won the silver medal of the [[Football at the 1966 Asian Games
column2: Asian Games in Thailand]]. He won the [[Asian Nations Cup]] with Iran in [[1968 Asian Cup
column3: 1968]] – when he scored 4 goals in 4 matches, also the equalizer in the final match, which led to 2–1 victory against Israel (and to become one of the tournament's top scorer). He also won the [[Asian Nations Cup]] with Iran in [[1972 Asian Cup

column1: Before his starting his coaching career, he trained [[Persepolis F.C.
column2: Persepolis]] in the absence of manager [[Alan Rogers (football manager)
column3: Alan Rogers]], when he was part of the team. After he retired in 1975, he became caretaker head coach of the club after resignation of Rogers. He starts a project in Persepolis that held in next years to decrease the age of the first team squad. His first match as the Persepolis match was a friendly against [[Malavan F.C.
column4: Malavan]] which won 3–1. His first official match was a loss to [[Rah Ahan F.C.
column5: Rah Ahan]]. After that, Persepolis won and drew twice, then faced to the rivals, [[Esteghlal F.C.
column6: Taj]] (now Esteghlal) in [[Tehran derby]]. He lost the match 3–1, but after the match he claimed that Taj players drugs before the match. It was later rejected. He was banned for two months and was replaced with [[Buyuk Vatankhah]]. After he was sacked as Persepolis head coach, he was manager of [[Shahbaz F.C.
column7: Shahbaz]] B team for more than ten years.

column4: Homayoun Behzadi scoring a goal against [[Taj SC
column5: Taj]] (Esteghlal) during the well-known Shishtayiha Match in [[Tehran derby]]]]

column1: He was named as one of the members of [[Persepolis F.C.]] Hall of Fame and the club thanked him for his great performance during his senior career at Persepolis. The club gave him a statue of his face and named him as one of the twelve great players of Persepolis in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web

column1: He suffered a heart attack and was transferred to [[Tehran]] hospital in April 2013. After two days, he was transferred to Day hospital and his personal doctor announced that his general health is good. He was released on 12 May 2013.
On 22 January 2016, Behzadi died in his home at the age of 74.

'''Homayoun Behzadi''' (20 June 1942 – 22 January 2016) was an Iranian [[Association football
column2: footballer]] and coach. He usually played as a [[Striker (association football)

column1: He was born on 4 January 1942 in [[Khorramabad]], [[Lorestan Province]]. Behzadi first broke into the [[Shahin F.C.
column2: Shahin]] side when he was only 16 years old. He played for Shahin until 1966, when – due to financial problems – Shahin closed. He is graduated in [[Persian language]].

column1: In 1967, he changed to [[Paykan Tehran F.C.
column2: Paykan]], then he changed to [[Persepolis F.C.
column3: Persepolis]] in spring 1968. Because of a heavy injury happened in the [[1968 Asian Cup]], his contract was dissolved, and Behzadi went back to Peykan. There he won the Tehran Championship in 1970 before changing to [[Persepolis F.C.
column4: Persepolis]] in 1970. There he won the Iranian league in [[1971–72 Local League
column5: 1972]] as well as in [[1973–74 Takht Jamshid Cup

column1: In 1966 he won the silver medal of the [[Football at the 1966 Asian Games
column2: Asian Games in Thailand]]. He won the [[Asian Nations Cup]] with Iran in [[1968 Asian Cup
column3: 1968]] – when he scored 4 goals in 4 matches, also the equalizer in the final match, which led to 2–1 victory against Israel (and to become one of the tournament's top scorer). He also won the [[Asian Nations Cup]] with Iran in [[1972 Asian Cup

column1: Before his starting his coaching career, he trained [[Persepolis F.C.
column2: Persepolis]] in the absence of manager [[Alan Rogers (football manager)
column3: Alan Rogers]], when he was part of the team. After he retired in 1975, he became caretaker head coach of the club after resignation of Rogers. He starts a project in Persepolis that held in next years to decrease the age of the first team squad. His first match as the Persepolis match was a friendly against [[Malavan F.C.
column4: Malavan]] which won 3–1. His first official match was a loss to [[Rah Ahan F.C.
column5: Rah Ahan]]. After that, Persepolis won and drew twice, then faced to the rivals, [[Esteghlal F.C.
column6: Taj]] (now Esteghlal) in [[Tehran derby]]. He lost the match 3–1, but after the match he claimed that Taj players drugs before the match. It was later rejected. He was banned for two months and was replaced with [[Buyuk Vatankhah]]. After he was sacked as Persepolis head coach, he was manager of [[Shahbaz F.C.
column7: Shahbaz]] B team for more than ten years.

column4: Homayoun Behzadi scoring a goal against [[Taj SC
column5: Taj]] (Esteghlal) during the well-known Shishtayiha Match in [[Tehran derby]]]]

column3: Mapo-gu}}) is one of the 25 [[List of districts of Seoul

column1: Mapo has a population of 381,330 (2015) and has a geographic area of 23.87 [[Square kilometre
column2: km<sup>2</sup>]] (9.22 [[sq mi]]), and is divided into 24 ''[[Dong (administrative division)
column3: dong]]'' (administrative neighborhoods). Mapo is located in western Seoul on the northern bank of the [[Han River (Korea)
column4: Han River]], bordering the [[Gyeonggi Province]] city of [[Goyang]] to the northwest, and the Seoul city districts of [[Gangseo District, Seoul
column7: Yongsan]] to the southeast, [[Jung District, Seoul
column8: Jung]] to the east, and [[Seodaemun District

column1: Mapo is home to several universities and government buildings, and is well known for the [[Hongdae area
column2: Hongdae]] club district around [[Hongik University]].  Mapo is connected to the [[Seoul Metropolitan Subway]]'s [[Seoul Subway Line 2
column6: Airport Railroad]], and the [[Korail]] [[Gyeongui-Jungang Line]] all pass through this district. The [[Seoul World Cup Stadium]], a famous landmark in Seoul, is located in [[Sangam-dong

column1: Mapo District Office is located in Seongsan-2 precinct, near World Cup Stadium (5 minutes on foot). Seoul Metropolitan Subway Line 6 passes near the office, and it has a station name \"Mapo-gu Office\" {{convert

The district office has 5 Bureaus, 1 Community Health Center, 36 Divisions, 1 Room, 1 Task Force Team, 16 Community Service Centers. Mapo District Office employs about 1,300 personnels. The entire office is headed by Administrator. Current Administrator is Hong-seop Park (2017).
Mapo District was formed in 1944 from portions of [[Seodaemun District
column2: Seodaemun]] and [[Yongsan District]]s.  The ''dong'' structure was revised in 1985 and 2008. Roughly 53% of Mapo District's area is taken up by residences, many of which are high-rise apartment buildings.  Much of the remaining area (43%) is greenspace, including the World Cup Park and additional parkland along the Han River.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Mapo District recently revamped its precincts (2008). The revision aimed to merge some precincts into one big precincts. This effectively reduces number of administrative office for precincts. As a result, the number of precinct offices decreased to 16 from 24. However, the administrative revamp did not change the address system.
The name \"Mapo\" comes from the name of an old ferry across the Han River, and can roughly be translated as \"hemp ferry.\"
Four college or university institutions, including [[Sogang University]] and [[Hongik University]], are located within Mapo District. The area around Hongik University, also known as [[Hongdae, Seoul
column2: Hongdae]], is well known as one of the cultural centers of Seoul, and was named one of the coolest neighborhoods in the world in 2016.<ref>{{cite
column4: title=The 15 Coolest Neighborhoods in the World in 2016
column5: accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref> There are eight high schools, including [[Seoul Girls' High School]], along with 12 middle schools and 20 elementary schools serving the community. There are three special schools for handicapped or industrial educations. Due to the presence of university students in the district, Mapo District offers a large variety of shopping and dining options. The area around [[Ewha Women's University]] is known for its affordable yet trendy merchandise, while neighboring Shinchon has an enormous number of take out and sit down restaurants.

column1: *[[Japanese School in Seoul]] in [[Sangam-dong]]<ref>[http://www.sjs.or.kr/ Home page] {{Webarchive
column3: date=2015-03-19 }}. [[Japanese School in Seoul]]. Retrieved on January 15, 2015. [http://www.sjs.or.kr/img/copy.jpg See address here] \"ソウル特別市麻浦区上岩洞1582\"</ref>

column1: Minor intro tweak, done!,safe,Quite A Character,"{{Spanish name
'''Antoni Ramallets Simón''' (1 July 1924 – 30 July 2013) was a Spanish [[Association football
He spent most of his career at [[FC Barcelona
column2: Barcelona]], winning the [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy]] as the best goalkeeper in [[La Liga]] on five occasions and 18 total honours.<ref>[http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/noticias/20090713/53743727820/las-85-vidas-del-gato-con-alas.html Las 85 vidas del 'Gato con Alas' azulgrana (The 85 lives of the blaugrana 'Winged Cat')]; [[La Vanguardia]], 13 July 2009 {{in lang
column3: es}}</ref> He represented [[Spain national football team
column4: Spain]] in the [[1950 FIFA World Cup

column1: Ramallets managed several teams in his country in the 60s, notably winning two major trophies with [[Real Zaragoza

Born in [[Barcelona]], [[Catalonia]], Ramallets signed for [[FC Barcelona]] in 1947 at the age of 23 from [[Real Valladolid]], where he also spent his first season after being purchased, on loan. He returned to the club to play second-fiddle to [[Juan Zambudio Velasco
column2: Juan Velasco]], making his [[La Liga]] debut in a 2–1 victory over [[Sevilla FC]] on 28 November 1948. Although this was his only appearance during [[1948–49 La Liga
column3: the season]] he eventually became the starter, being an essential defensive unit as his team – then named Club de Fútbol Barcelona – went on to conquer six leagues and five [[Copa del Rey
column5: 1951–52]], as they won five major trophies, he contributed with 28 league games, being awarded his first [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy]].

column1: During the 1950s, Ramallets was a prominent member of the successful Barcelona side that also included [[Joan Segarra]], [[Marià Gonzalvo]], [[László Kubala]], [[Sándor Kocsis]], [[Evaristo de Macedo
column3: Luis Suárez]] and [[Zoltán Czibor]].<ref>[https://www.fcbarcelona.es/es/ficha/643900/1950-61-kubala-y-su-tiempo# 1950–61. Kubala y su tiempo (1950–61. Kubala and his time)]; FC Barcelona, 13 March 2018 {{in lang
column4: es}}</ref> During his spell with the club he made 538 appearances, including 288 in the domestic league; on 6 March 1962 the ''Blaugrana'' played a [[Testimonial match
column5: testimonial]] in his honour against [[Hamburger SV]], winning 5–1.<ref>[https://www.rtve.es/deportes/20130730/fallece-ramallets-mitico-portero-del-barcelona-89-anos/727721.shtml Fútbol {{!}} Obituarios – Fallece Ramallets, mítico portero del Barcelona, a los 89 años (Football {{!}} Deaths – Death of Ramallets, legendary Barcelona goalkeeper, at the age of 89)]; [[RTVE]], 30 July 2013 {{in lang
column6: es}}</ref><ref>[https://elpais.com/deportes/2013/07/30/actualidad/1375199929_294426.html Antoni Ramallets, el portero sin guantes que saltaba como un gato (Antoni Ramallets, the goalkeeper without gloves who jumped like a cat)]; [[El País]], 30 July 2013 {{in lang

column1: Ramallets coached several teams over the following decade, including old acquaintance Valladolid. In the [[1963–64 La Liga
column2: 1963–64 campaign]] he led [[Real Zaragoza]] to the fourth place in the league, the [[1963–64 Copa del Generalísimo
column3: Spanish Cup]] and the [[1963–64 Inter-Cities Fairs Cup
column4: Inter-Cities Fairs Cup]] – a competition he had won twice as a player with Barcelona – defeating fellow league team [[Valencia CF]] in the latter.<ref>[https://www.elperiodicodearagon.com/noticias/deportes/fallece-ramallets-entrenador-real-zaragoza-epoca-magnificos_872762.html Fallece Ramallets, entrenador del Real Zaragoza en la época de los Magníficos (Death of Ramallets, manager of Real Zaragoza during the age of the Magnificent)]; [[El Periódico de Aragón]], 31 July 2013 {{in lang

column1: Ramallets played 35 games for [[Spain national football team
column2: Spain]] during 11 years, making his debut against [[Chile national football team
column3: Chile]] on 29 June 1950, during the [[1950 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil.<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/ramallets-intl.html Antonio Ramallets Simón – International Appearances] {{webarchive
column5: date=8 July 2007}}; at [[RSSSF]]</ref> During the tournament he earned the nickname ''The Cat of [[Estádio do Maracanã
column6: Maracaná]]'', helping the nation to the second group stage.<ref>[https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/mundial-futbol/gato-maracana-3294730 Ramallets, el gato de Maracaná (Ramallets, the cat of Maracaná)]; [[Sport (Spanish newspaper)

column1: Ramallets also played seven games for the unofficial [[Catalonia national football team

Ramallets died in his [[Vilafranca del Penedès]] home near Barcelona, on 31 July 2013. He was 89 years old.<ref>[http://www.mundodeportivo.com/20130730/fc-barcelona/ramallets-muerte-fallecimiento_54379004856.html Ha muerto Antoni Ramallets (Antoni Ramallets has died)] {{Webarchive
column4: es}}</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.es/deportes/futbol/20130730/abci-muere-ramallets-barcelona-201307301753.html Fallece a los 89 años Antoni Ramallets, el mítico portero del Barcelona (Antoni Ramallets, legendary Barcelona goalkeeper, dies at the age of 89)]; [[ABC (newspaper)
column6: es}}</ref><ref>[http://www.euronews.com/2013/07/31/former-spain-keeper-ramallets-dies-aged-89/ Former Spain keeper Ramallets dies aged 89]; [[Euronews]], 31 July 2013</ref>
