column5: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref>) is a Czech fine art creator who works with the urban environment and iconography of the city. His interventions frequently focus on contemporary social topics and regularly addresses issues surrounding [[public space]]. His identity has remained unknown to date.<ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite web
column7: title=\"Bývalý\" graffiťák EPOS 257 pro INFO.CZ: Město se musí měnit. Nedá se nad tím brečet
column11: trans-title=\"Former\" graffiti EPOS 257 for INFO.CZ: The city has to change. You can't cry over it}}</ref>

column1: Born in the 1980s in Prague, Epos 257 started his career as a writer (a person who creates graffiti - street art sub-culture jargon). Some principle characteristics of [[graffiti]] can still be traced in the artist's work. Above all, it is the invasive nature of the work, the insider's awareness of the urban landscape and the conscious movement on the edge of the law or beyond.<ref>{{Cite book
column2: title=The world atlas of street art and graffiti
column15: oclc=649799098}}</ref> Epos 257 is a graduate of the [[Academy of Arts, Architecture and Design in Prague
column16: Academy of Arts, Architecture and Design]]<ref name=\"auto\"/> and a member of the interdisciplinary group [[Ztohoven]]<ref name=\"auto\"/>

column1: Epos 257's art is characterised by examination of public space, especially the way it is used and the limits of what is and is not public.<ref name=\"auto\"/> He repeatedly challenges the creation in public with its institutional conception.<ref name=\"auto1\">{{Cite interview
column5: title=Snažím se propojit galerii s ulicí, říká Epos 257 {{!}} Aktuálně.cz
column6: website=Aktuálně.cz - Víte, co se právě děje
column9: trans-title=I'm trying to connect the gallery to the street, says Epos 257}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> He has five solo and several collective exhibitions at home and abroad to his name.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In 2009, Epos 257 anonymously placed more than thirty bales of [[hay]] around the centre of Prague, as it is done after harvesting in the countryside. However, his actions were subsequently interpreted (especially by the tabloid media) as a public threat and even associated with [[terrorism]].<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=Radio Wave}}</ref> After some time, he repeated this undertaking as part of the implementation for the [[National Theatre (Prague)
column6: National Theater]] on the Piazzetta of the [[National Theatre (Prague)
column7: National Theater]] (renamed to [[Václav Havel]] Square), albeit this time intentionally obtaining all the required official permissions<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

column1: A year later, Epos continued dealing with the boundaries of public space, even in the context of legislation. At that time, he put up a fence around space on [[Palackého náměstí (Praha)
column2: Palackeho Square]] (on which there is an exemption to the law prohibiting public gatherings without notice, and which is therefore referred to as the Czech “[[Hyde Park, London
column3: Hyde Park]]”), around an area of 50 square meters. Inside the delimited space, nothing was happening or placed other than what was outside of it. The absurd enclosure lasted 54 days on the square. After such a long time, the artist himself contacted city officials. This work was connected to the pointing out the indifference to the use of public space and the unjustifiableness of certain restrictions associated with it.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Epos 257 v Bourání: Graffiti je indikátor opuštěnosti místa, ale i svobody
column10: trans-title=Epic 257 in Demolition: Graffiti is an indicator of the abandonment of place, but also of freedom}}</ref>

column1: Epos 257 has also repeatedly devoted himself to [[billboard]]s. For example, In the Portrait project, which was realised before the Czech presidential elections in 2013, he cut out the giant faces of both the final candidates, smiling at people from their gigantic posters, and then framed them. While he left the remains of the promotional posters lacking the faces of politicians in the original place. Epos installed the framed and glazed representations opposite each other. Shortly after his election, Epos went on to place a gigantic portrait of the winner of the elections [[Miloš Zeman]] in the [[Czech National Library of Technology
column4: title=Epos 257: Umělec, který prodal zarámovanou loupež {{!}} Recenze

column1: It was mainly for his “billboard” projects that Epos 257 was repeatedly associated with breaking the law. His actions before the presidential and municipal elections also revived the debate on the ethical boundaries of artistic creation. The artist did, however, fully compensate the billboard owners for the financial damages he caused in 2013 by cutting out the heads of the presidential candidates<ref>{{Cite web

column4: title=Jack Greene, Jeannie Seely -- ''Greatest Hits'' (1982, Vinyl)

column2: prev_title = Live at the Grand Ole Opry

column1: '''''Greatest Hits''''' is a studio album by American [[country music
column2: country]] country artists [[Jack Greene]] and [[Jeannie Seely]]. It was released in 1982 and was co-produced by Tommy Hill and Moe Lytle for [[Gusto Records]]. Although titled as ''Greatest Hits'', the album contained new recordings of songs that Greene and Seely cut for the Gusto label. These recordings were remakes of original tunes that both artists had previously cut themselves.

column1: It would later be reissued in different formats. In 1994, the album was reissued on [[Hollywood Records]] with an identical track listing to the original.

''Greatest Hits'' was recorded in the fall of 1981 at the Gusto Recording Studio, which was located in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. The sessions were co-produced by Tommy Hill and Moe Lytle.<ref name=\"Liner Notes\">{{cite journal
column6: title=''Greatest Hits'' (Liner Notes and Album Information)
column8: date=1982}}</ref> The original release of the album consisted of ten tracks. Some of these tracks were solo recordings while some were [[duet]]s between Greene and Seely.<ref name=\"Discogs\"/> Regardless of lead vocalist credits, all songs had been previously recorded by both artists. Among the solo re-recordings was the song \"[[There Goes My Everything (song)
column9: There Goes My Everything]]\" by Greene. In 1967, Greene recorded the original version which became a number 1 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column11: country songs chart]]. Another solo re-recording was \"[[Don't Touch Me]]\" by Seely. In 1966, Seely had cut the original version which became a number 2 hit on the ''Billboard'' country chart and won a [[Grammy Award]].<ref name=\"Liner Notes\"/>

column1: Two previously unrecorded tracks were featured on the album as well. The seventh track, \"We Don't Want the World\", was a new duet between Greene and Seely. The tenth track, \"Beautiful Lady\", was a new solo recording by Greene.<ref name=\"Liner Notes\"/> The album also included duet re-recordings. Among these was the track \"[[Wish I Didn't Have to Miss You]]\".<ref name=\"Liner Notes\"/> The original recording on [[Decca Records]] became a major hit in 1970, reaching number 2 on the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=7 April 2020}}</ref> In 1982 ''Greatest Hits'' first released on [[Gusto Records]] as a [[gramophone record
column8: vinyl record]], with five songs on side one and five songs on side two.<ref name=\"Discogs\"/> The original album release promoted two 1981 singles released on Gusto: \"There Goes My Everything\" and \"Don't Touch Me\".<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book

column1: In 1994, the album was reissued on [[Hollywood Records]] in [[audio cassette
column2: cassette]] and [[compact disc]] formats.<ref name=\"Amazon\">{{cite web

The '''Ornate Butterflyfish''', '''Chaetodon ornatissimus''', is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish, Clown Butterfly, Coralfishes, Ornate Butterfly, Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish
column2: Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish
column3: Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler, Jennifer L., and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”, but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish, it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon, which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish
column4: Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these, they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout, and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon
column2: lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\">Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.</ref>. Juvenile ornate butterflyfish are solitary and can be found singly, living in the arms of branching corals, but form pairs during breeding <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics
column2: tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]], the [[Marquesas Islands
column3: Marquesas]], the [[Pitcairn Islands]], North to Southern [[Japan]], South to Lord Howe, and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández, Sebastián, et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut
column4: Hsu, Kui-Ching; Chen, Jeng-Ping & Shao, Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine, inshore, tropical (30°N - 30°S, 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers, R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada, Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile, benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms, unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett, M. S., Wilson, S. K., & Baird, A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology'', ''69''(5), 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing, pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however, by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish, specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish, and localized extinctions, following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al., revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growthBrooker, R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6''', 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development. Coral reef communities provide shelter, and food resources for Butterflyfish. However, the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish, as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species, which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish
column15: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores, which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)
column18: Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore, butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral, and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake, sprint, turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'' '''14''': 77–86. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070811042056/http://rmbr.nus.edu.sg/rbz/biblio/s14/s14rbz10_Hsu-pp77-86.pdf PDF fulltext]

column1: The '''Ornate Butterflyfish''', '''Chaetodon ornatissimus''', is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish, Clown Butterfly, Coralfishes, Ornate Butterfly, Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish
column2: Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish
column3: Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler, Jennifer L., and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”, but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish, it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon, which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish
column4: Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these, they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout, and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon
column2: lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\">Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.</ref>. Juvenile ornate butterflyfish are solitary and can be found singly, living in the arms of branching corals, but form pairs during breeding <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\" />.

column3: Marquesas]], the [[Pitcairn Islands]], North to Southern [[Japan]], South to Lord Howe, and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández, Sebastián, et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut

''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine, inshore, tropical (30°N - 30°S, 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers, R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada, Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

''Stray Bullets''}}) is the second studio album by the Colombian band [[Morat (band)
column3: Morat]]. The album was released on October 26, 2018.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=TODO LO QUE SABEMOS SOBRE ‘BALAS PERDIDAS’, EL NUEVO DISCO DE MORAT
column12: publisher=Los40}}</ref> The re-issue version was released on May 10, 2019, which includes the song \"[[Presiento]]\" in collaboration with [[Aitana]].<ref>{{cite news

column2: Morat]] began to gain international attention as a result of their 2015 hit single \"[[Mi Nuevo Vicio]]\" in collaboration with [[Paulina Rubio]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Estreno mundial de Paulina feat. Morat 'Mi nuevo Vicio'
column8: publisher=[[Mediaset España]]}}</ref> The single was certified a Platinum Record.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Terelu entregó el disco de Platino a Paulina Rubio por sus ventas de ‘Mi nuevo vicio’

column1: In 2016, Morat released their first studio album ''[[Sobre el amor y sus efectos secundarios]]'', continuing making waves in the Latin music scene. Morat obtained 4x Platinum Record as well as a Latin Grammy award nomination for \"Cómo te atreves\", and Golden Record for \"Cuánto me duele\"<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Morat presentará su disco 'Sobre el amor y sus efectos secundarios' el 9 de marzo en Granada
column5: date=30 January 2017}}</ref>, which are two singles of this album.

column1: In 2017, Morat produced the single \"[[Yo contigo, tú conmigo (The Gong Gong Song)
column2: Yo Contigo, Tú Conmigo (The Gong Gong Song)]]\" in collaboration with [[Álvaro Soler]] as the theme music of [[Despicable Me 3]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=MORAT Y ÁLVARO SOLER PONEN MÚSICA A ‘GRU 3. MI VILLANO FAVORITO’, A LA VENTA EL 16 DE JUNIO
column5: date=12 June 2017}}</ref> The single peaked at No.9 on Billboard on August 19, 2017<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Chart History Morat \"Yo Contigo, Tú Conmigo\"}}</ref> and won the \"Song of the Year\" award in [[LOS40 Music Awards 2017]].<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=‘YO CONTIGO, TÚ CONMIGO’ EN DIRECTO EN LOS40 MUSIC AWARDS

column1: Juan Pablo Villamil, one of the four members, said that they wanted to \"do some experimentation\" in this album. He described this album as \"more of a solid album\", saying that it is very different due to their recording experience in one trip to Los Angeles. He believed that in this album \"there's more like one sound and it sounds more like an album\", unlike the first album, which he thought \"the songs sound very different one from another\" as \"it was recorded song by song throughout many years\".<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Interview: Morat talks first U.S. tour & how the folk-pop band fits in today's Latin music scene

column1: In regards to \"No se va\", one of the singles in this album, Juan Pablo Villamil admitted that this song is \"quite different from the others\", describing it as \"more of a dancing type of song\". He said that they wanted to \"do something more upbeat\" in this song.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Interview: Morat talks first U.S. tour & how the folk-pop band fits in today's Latin music scene

column1: On November 3, 2017, Morat released \"Besos en guerra\" in collaboration with [[Juanes]]. On June 8, 2018, 7 months after \"Besos en guerra\", Morat released the second single of the album, \"Cuando nadie ve\". On July 6, 2018, the third single of the album, \"Punto y aparte\", was released. On September 13, 2018, Morat released the fourth single of the album, \"El embrujo\", in collaboration with [[Antonio Carmona]] and Josemi Carmona. Finally, on October 26, 2018, the album was released with the title \"Balas perdidas\". On the same day, the fifth single of the album, \"Yo no merezco volver\", was released.
On March 7, 2019, Morat released the sixth single of the album, \"No se va\", which hit almost 2 million visits on Youtube in less than a week.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=MORAT PRESENTAN EL VIDEOCLIP DE ‘NO SE VA’

column1: On April 4, 2019, Morat performed in San Francisco, kicking off their first-ever US tour, with the title \"Balas perdidas\" to promote their album. The tour ended in Orlando on May 5, 2019, with performance in other cities such as Los Angeles, Chicago, and New York.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Morat Ready to Bring Their Colombian Flavor to the U.S. With Balas Perdidas Tour
column7: title=Morat kicked off their “Balas Perdidas US Tour”

column1: On May 10, 2019, the re-issue of Balas perdidas, ''Balas perdidas (Edición especial)'', was released, which includes \"[[Presiento]]\" in collaboration with [[Aitana]] and three other songs.<ref>{{cite news
On December 15, 2019, Morat ended their Spain tour with the last performance at the [[Palacio de Deportes de la Comunidad de Madrid
column2: WiZink Center]] in Madrid. Antonio José, [[Aitana]], [[Cali y El Dandee]], and [[Cami]] were also invited to perform at this concert.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Morat cierra su gira ‘Balas Perdidas’ en Madrid y anuncia su vuelta en 2020
column6: date=16 December 2019}}</ref> Up to this show, Morat has held more than 80 concerts in 13 different countries.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=MADRID SE RINDE ANTE MORAT EN SU ÚLTIMA “BALA PERDIDA”

column1: On Billboard, the second single \"Cuando nadie ve\" peaked at No.1 on August 18, 2018, and the single \"[[Presiento]]\" peaked at No.3 on July 20, 2019.<ref>{{cite web

The single \"[[Presiento]]\" received more than 600,000 streams in [[Spotify]] in its first 24 hours. After that period of time, \"Presiento\" became the song with the highest debut in Spain, with more than 230,000 streams there, beating [[Rosalía (singer)
column2: Rosalía]] and [[J Balvin]]'s 2019 track \"[[Con altura]]\".<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=‘Presiento’ de Morat y Aitana, mejor debut del año en Spotify España

column2: awards            = Fellow, [[National Academy of Public Administration]]

American]] [[political scientist]] and scholar of [[public policy]] and [[public administration]]. She is the Frank and June Sackton Professor of Urban Policy at [[Arizona State University]], where she is also Director of the School of Public Affairs and a Distinguished Sustainability Scholar at the Julie Ann Wrigley Global Institute of Sustainability.<ref>{{cite web
column6: access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=profile/> She is an expert on the [[Diffusion of innovations#Policy
column7: diffusion]] and implementation of policy ideas, with a particular focus on the politics of [[internet access]] in the United States.

column1: Mossberger attended [[Wayne State University]], where she earned three degrees: a BA in political science in 1991, an MA in political science in 1992, and a PhD in political science in 1996.<ref name=profile>{{cite web
column6: access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> During the 1992–1993 academic year, she was a visiting researcher at the [[University of Strathclyde]].<ref name=profile/>

column1: In 1996 Mossberger joined [[Eastern Michigan University]] as a lecturer, moving in 1997 to [[Kent State University]].<ref name=profile/> While a professor at Kent State University, Mossberger was involved in a visiting faculty program with [[Tver State University]], [[Volgograd State University]], and [[Voronezh State University]], and for one year she served as the Interim Director of the Center for Public Administration and Public Policy there.<ref name=profile/> In 2005 she became a professor of public policy at the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]], where she later became both the Associate Dean for Faculty Affairs at the College of Urban Planning and Public Affairs and for 2 years was the Head of the Department of Public Administration.<ref name=profile/> In 2013 she became a Professor at the Arizona State University School of Public Affairs, where she was also the director for 4 years.<ref name=profile/> From 2014 to 2017, she was an honorary professor at the [[University of Birmingham]].<ref name=profile/>

In addition to her publications in peer reviewed journals and chapters in edited volumes, Mossberger has published several books. In 2000 she published ''The Politics of Ideas and the Spread of Enterprise Zones'', of which she was the sole author.<ref>{{cite journal
column2: title=Review of The Politics of Ideas and the Spread of Enterprise Zones
column6: pages=127}}</ref> The book studies how the concept of [[Urban enterprise zone
column7: enterprise zones]] spread in the United States, using the tools of policy diffusion.<ref>{{cite journal
column10: title=Review of The Politics of Ideas and the Spread of Enterprise Zones
column16: doi=}}</ref> Mossberger focuses on five states from 1981 to 1993: Indiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, and Virginia.<ref name=heineman>{{cite journal
column19: title=Review of The Politics of Ideas and the Spread of Enterprise Zones
column24: pages=106}}</ref> As part of the her analysis of the diffusion and implementation of this idea throughout several regions, Mossberger also draws conclusions about the dynamics of decision-making in a [[Federalism
column25: federalist]] system, and under what conditions these decisions are [[Homo economicus
column29: title=Review of The Politics of Ideas and the Spread of Enterprise Zones
column30: journal=The Politics of Ideas and the Spread of Enterprise Zones

column1: In 2013, together with [[Caroline Tolbert]] and William Franko, Mossberger published the book ''Digital Cities: The Internet and the Geography of Opportunity''. The book defines the notion of \"digital citizenship\" to capture the extent to which individuals are capable of regularly and effectively using technology related to the internet.<ref name=lseblog>{{cite web
column3: title=Book Review: Digital Cities: The Internet and the Geography of Opportunity by Karen Mossberger et al
column8: access-date=26 February 2020}}</ref> The authors focus on inequality in peoples' capacities to use internet technologies; Zachary Spicer, in a review of the book, wrote that they demonstrate that \"America is falling short in these areas and, as a result, information inequities are developing that could have deep and lasting impacts on the social fabric of the country.\"<ref name=lseblog/> The book also presents policy suggestions for making digital citizenship more equal.<ref name=lseblog/>

column1: Mossberger's 2008 book ''Digital Citizenship: The Internet, Society and Participation'', coauthored with Caroline J. Tolbert and Ramona S. McNeal, was named one of the top 20 social science titles for 2008 by the [[American Library Association]].<ref name=profile/> The book was issued in a second printing in 2010. Mossberger is also the author of ''Virtual Inequality: Beyond the Digital Divide'' with Caroline J. Tolbert and Mary Stansbury (2003), and ''The Oxford Handbook of Urban Politics'' with  Susan E. Clarke and Peter John (2012).<ref name=profile/>

Several of Mossberger's journal articles have also won best paper awards. Her 2006 article with Caroline J. Tolbert, titled \"The Effects of E-Government on Trust and Confidence in Government\", was published in The ''[[Public Administration Review]]'', and was subsequently named by the journal as one of the 75 most influential articles ever published there since the journal's founding in 1940.<ref>{{cite web
column6: access-date=26 February 2020}}</ref> The paper was also listed as a Classic Paper by ''[[Google Scholar]]'', which recognizes \"highly-cited papers in their area of research that have stood the test of time\".<ref name=classic>{{cite web
column11: access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> Her 2005 paper \"Race, Place, and Information Technology\" received the 2005 Best Paper Award from the Public Policy Section of the [[American Political Science Association]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: publisher=American Political Science Association Public Policy Section

column1: In 2016,<ref name=profile/> Mossberger was named a Fellow of the American [[National Academy of Public Administration]].<ref name=fellow>{{cite web
column3: title=Professor Mary Feeney selected as a National Academy of Public Administration fellow

column1: Mossberger's work has been cited, or she has been quoted, in news outlets like the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'',<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Orland Park residents could be rewarded for civic involvement

column19: title=The digital divide is much wider than you think

American]] [[political scientist]] and scholar of [[public policy]] and [[public administration]]. She is the Frank and June Sackton Professor of Urban Policy at [[Arizona State University]], where she is also Director of the School of Public Affairs and a Distinguished Sustainability Scholar at the Julie Ann Wrigley Global Institute of Sustainability.<ref>{{cite web
column6: access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=profile/> She is an expert on the [[Diffusion of innovations#Policy

'''Carl Sanford Joslyn \"Sandy\" Petersen''' (born September 16, 1955) is an American [[game designer]].
Petersen was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] and attended [[University of California, Berkeley]], majoring in [[zoology]].

He is a well-known fan of [[H. P. Lovecraft]], whose work he first encountered in a [[World War II]] [[Armed Services Edition]] of ''[[The Dunwich Horror and other Weird Tales]]'' found in his father's library. In 1974, ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' brought his interest to [[role-playing game]]s.{{citation needed
column2: date=September 2013}} He became a full-time staff member at [[Chaosium]].<ref name=\"designers\">{{Cite book
column8: pages=86}}</ref> His interest for role-playing games and H. P. Lovecraft were fused when he became principal author of Chaosium's game ''[[Call of Cthulhu (role-playing game)
column9: Call of Cthulhu]]'', published 1981,<ref name=\"Dragon197\">{{cite journal
column16: pages=57–62}}</ref> and many scenarios and background pieces thereafter.<ref name=\"HG\">{{Cite book
column29: isbn=978-1-932442-96-0}}</ref> While working for Chaosium he co-authored the third edition of ''[[RuneQuest]]'', for which he also co-wrote the critically acclaimed ''[[Trollpak]]'' and a number of other [[Glorantha]]n supplements.{{citation needed

column1: He authored several critically acclaimed ''RuneQuest'' supplements for [[Avalon Hill]] and [[Games Workshop]].<ref name=\"HG\"/> Petersen served as co-designer for [[West End Games]]'s ''[[Ghostbusters (role-playing game)
column2: Ghostbusters]]'' roleplaying game.<ref name=\"HG\"/> He still plays and runs role-playing games, and is a frequent guest at conventions where he usually runs a [[Freeform role-playing game
column3: freeform game]] of his own devising, and/or helps to run someone else's game.

column1: He worked some time for [[MicroProse]], where he is credited for work on ''[[Sid Meier's Pirates!]]'' and ''[[Sword of the Samurai (computer game)
column2: Sword of the Samurai]]''.<ref name=\"HG\"/> Between 1989 and 1992 he also worked on the [[video game]]s ''[[Darklands (computer game)
column5: Lightspeed]]''. He also made some contributions to ''[[Civilization (computer game)

column1: Primarily interested by the [[first-person shooter]] ''[[Wolfenstein 3D]]'', Petersen joined [[id Software]] about 10 weeks before the December 1993 release of ''[[Doom (1993 video game)
column2: Doom]]'' and in that time created 19 [[Level (computer and video games)
column3: level]]s for it (of which 8 were based to some extent on early drafts by [[Tom Hall]]). He later created 17 of the levels for ''[[Doom II]]'', and 7 levels for ''[[Quake (video game)
column4: Quake]]''. His Lovecraftian influences also resulted in some changes to the monster designs for these games.

column1: He left id Software for [[Ensemble Studios]] in June 1997.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Ensemble's Second Title Picks Up Speed
column11: archivedate=December 3, 1998}}</ref> There, he has worked as a game designer on several of their ''[[Age of Empires]]'' titles, including ''[[Age of Empires: The Rise of Rome Expansion
column12: Rise of Rome]]'', ''[[Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings
column13: Age of Kings]]'', and ''[[Age of Empires II: The Conquerors Expansion
column14: The Conquerors]]''.<ref name=\"HG\"/> During this time, he was a frequent poster on the HeavenGames forums under the username ES_Sandyman. He ran an extremely popular series of threads, \"Ask Sandyman\", where forum members could ask him about anything they wanted.

column1: Petersen was the Executive Producer for the 2011 movie [[The Whisperer in Darkness (film)
column2: The Whisperer in Darkness]] which was nominated for awards at the [[Chicago International Film Festival
column3: Chicago]] and [[Warsaw International Film Festival]]s. It was produced by H.P. Lovecraft Historical Society Motion Pictures in the style of a 1930s black and white [[horror movie]].

column2: date=December 2013}} serves as the publisher of horror magazine ''Arcane: Penny Dreadfuls for the 21st Century''.<ref name=\"Arcane Webpage\">[http://www.arcanemagazine.com/ Arcane: Penny Dreadfuls for the 21st Century].</ref>

column1: Petersen took a professorship at [[The Guildhall at SMU]] in 2009 following the closure of [[Ensemble Studios]], where he taught several courses on [[game design]].<ref name=\"Guildhall Faculty Biographies\">[http://guildhall.smu.edu/Faculty.15.0.html?&cHash=2cfb264088&tx_guildhallbio_pi1 The Guildhall at SMU Faculty], Guildhall @ SMU Faculty Biographies.</ref>
Petersen worked at [[Barking Lizards Technologies]] as their Creative Director, after leaving The Guildhall, and worked on their iOS release, ''[[Osiris Legends]]''.
In mid-2013 Petersen led a highly successful [[Kickstarter]] campaign by his company, Green Eye Games, to produce the ''Cthulhu Wars'' boardgame. Over [[United States dollar
column2: US]]$1,400,000 was raised achieving over 3,500% of the initial target.  This success allowed the creation of more figures (60), map expansions and additional scenario options. In most, if not all, previous Cthulhu games \"you strive to avert the impending catastrophe. But in Cthulhu Wars you ARE the catastrophe! The Great Old Ones have returned to claim the ruins of Earth, and you are one of them!\"<ref>http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1816687860/cthulhu-wars?ref=home_popular</ref> Green Eye Games also produced the unsuccessful kickstarter ''Cthulhu World Combat'' (iOS, Android, Windows, PSN, Xbox Live).<ref name=\"Barking Lizards Management Team\">[http://www.barkinglizards.com/folks.html Barking Lizards Management Team].</ref><ref>http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1816687860/cthulhu-world-combat</ref><ref>http://www.cthulhuworldcombat.com {{webarchive

column1: In June 2015, it was announced that Petersen and [[Greg Stafford]] had returned to Chaosium Inc.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=GREG STAFFORD & SANDY PETERSEN REJOIN CHAOSIUM INC.

column1: Petersen is a practising member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]], but sees no conflict between his faith and his design of games involving Satanic elements. While working on ''Doom'', he said to [[John Romero]]: \"I have no problems with the demons in the game. They're just cartoons. And, anyway, ''they're'' the bad guys.\"<ref name=\"Masters of Doom\">{{cite book
column3: Masters of Doom: How Two Guys Created an Empire and Transformed Pop Culture]]

column1: Sandy is married, has five children, and nine grandchildren.<ref>http://www.chaosium.com/sandy-petersen/</ref>
* ''[[Age of Empires: The Rise of Rome]]'' (1998)
* ''[[Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings
* [http://aok.heavengames.com/gameinfo/ask-sandyman Ask Sandy Series @ Age of Kings Heaven (1999-2001)]

column3: title=Pen & Paper: Roleplaying Game Credits for Sandy Petersen

column2: it}} [http://www.rill.it/?q=node/497 An interview in Italian language on RiLL.it (2011)]

column4: title=The Ring Two – Box Office Data, DVD Sales, Movie News, Cast Information – The Numbers

column1: '''''The Ring Two''''' (stylized as '''''the ring twO''''') is a 2005 American [[supernatural]] [[psychological horror]] film and a [[sequel]] to the 2002 film ''[[The Ring (2002 film)
column2: The Ring]]'', which was a [[remake]] of the 1998 Japanese film ''[[Ring (film)
column3: Ringu]]''. [[Hideo Nakata]], director of the original Japanese film ''Ringu'', on which the American versions are based, directed this film in place of [[Gore Verbinski]].

column1: The film was shot in [[Astoria, Oregon]] and [[Los Angeles, California]]. It was released on March 18, 2005, and although it was met by generally negative critical reception, it opened in the United States with a strong [[US dollar
column2: US$]]35 million its first weekend, more than doubling the opening weekend of ''The Ring''. Its final $76 million domestic gross was less than the original's $129 million, but it took $85 million internationally, for a total gross of $161 million.

column1: It is the second installment in [[The Ring (franchise)
column2: ''The Ring'' film series]] and was followed by ''[[Rings (2017 film)

column1: Six months<!-- The short film ''Rings'' (2005) takes place in 2003 and this film is set in the same year, do not remove it --> after the events of the [[The Ring (2002 film)
column2: first film]] and immediately following the events of the short film ''[[Rings (2005 film)
column3: Rings]]'', [[Samara Morgan]]’s cursed videotape has been circulating through teenagers in [[Astoria, Oregon]]. Jake Pierce is on his seventh day as per the tape's rules, and asks his friend Emily to watch the tape. He briefly steps into his kitchen while Emily supposedly watches the tape. Jake receives a phone call and initially thinks it is Samara but is relieved to realize it is only his friend with whom he had planned to trick Emily into watching the tape. Suddenly, Jake notices dark liquid pouring from under the kitchen door and runs outside to the living room, only to discover Emily closed her eyes while watching the tape. Jake is then promptly murdered by Samara.

column1: [[Rachel Keller]] and her son, Aidan, have moved to Astoria from [[Seattle]] after sending the tape off into the ether. Rachel works at ''[[The Daily Astorian]]'' for editor Max Rourke. Rachel learns of Jake's death, inspecting his body, only for Samara to appear, declaring that she has been looking for her. Rachel breaks into Jake's house, obtains the videotape and burns it. Aidan experiences a [[nightmare]] where Samara drags him into a television. He soon starts developing [[hypothermia]] and bruises on his arms. At a [[county fair]], Aidan wanders into a restroom and takes photographs of his reflection, where Samara appears. Rachel takes him home but they are attacked by multiple wild deer on the way. Rachel realizes Aidan may be possessed by Samara.
Max takes them in. While Rachel is attempting to give Aidan a bath, he develops an irrational [[Aquaphobia
column2: fear of water]]. Samara causes the water to recede from the bath, replacing Aidan with herself, and terrorizing Rachel so that she tries to drown Samara. Max enters, seeing her drowning Aidan instead, and forces her to take her son to the hospital. Based on Aidan's bruises, psychiatrist Emma Temple suspects [[child abuse]] on the part of Rachel, who admits she had [[postpartum depression]], and she sends Rachel away. Looking for answers, Rachel returns to the Morgan ranch on Moesko Island, finding evidence of Samara's biological mother Evelyn, who tried to drown her as an infant. Rachel visits Evelyn in a [[psychiatric hospital]], who advises her to \"listen to her baby\".

column1: In the hospital, Samara takes control of Aidan's body and [[Mind control in popular culture
column2: telepathically forces]] Dr. Temple to commit suicide before returning to Max's house. Max arrives, suspects foul play, and tries to secretly take photos of Aidan. Rachel arrives, discovering an affectionate Aidan waiting for her, but acting suspiciously out-of-character. She steps out, finding Max's corpse in his pickup truck. Rachel falls asleep, dreaming of Aidan, who tells her that she will have to [[exorcism
column3: exorcise]] Samara. Upon awakening, Rachel drugs Samara with sleeping pills and places her in the bath to temporarily drown Aidan in order to exorcise her. Samara is removed but appears in the television. Rachel allows herself to be dragged into Samara's monochromatic world.

column1: Finding herself in the bottom of the [[water well
column2: well]] Samara died in, Rachel discovers the lid is partially open. She scales the well's walls, pursued by Samara, but escapes by climbing out and pushing the lid shut on Samara, locking her out of her and Aidan's lives.

column1: Wandering through the woods, she comes to the cliff where Samara's adoptive mother Anna committed suicide. Hearing Aidan's voice, Rachel falls off the cliff and falls into the water, returning to the real world and reuniting with Aidan.
* [[Mary Elizabeth Winstead]] as Young Evelyn Borden

On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has a rating of 20%, based on 189 reviews, with an average rating of 4.44/10. The site's critical consensus states: \"''Ring Two'' serves up horror cliches, and not even Hideo Nakata, the director of the movies from which this one is based, can save the movie from a dull screenplay full of absurdities.\"<ref name=\"rotten\">{{cite web
column6: weighted average]] score, gave the film a 44 out of 100 based on 37 reviews from critics.<ref name=\"metacritic\">{{cite web
column8: title=The Ring Two Reviews, Ratings, Credits
column11: accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]], however, considered it better than the first film, giving it 2½ stars and writing \"The charm of ''The Ring Two'', while limited, is real enough; it is based on the film's ability to make absolutely no sense, while nevertheless generating a real enough feeling of tension a good deal of the time.\"<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=The Ring Two Movie Review & Film Summary (2005)

column1: Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of \"C+\" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name=\"CinemaScore\">{{cite web

column2: Unrated Edition]] [[DVD]] release, a few extra scenes were included that were not in the theatrical release. These scenes included conversations with Rachel's new neighbor (and neighborhood gossip), numerous additions in which Max shows a romantic interest in Rachel, more scenes with Samara prior to her possession of Aidan (including one in which she is shown to enter him in the restroom at the local fair), and the short film ''[[Rings (2005 film)
column3: Rings]]'' (2005) (which was also included on a special edition of ''The Ring'' released just before ''The Ring Two'' arrived in theaters). A scene in the theatrical cut in which Aidan first encounters a deer while wandering the local fair (prior to the deer attack) has also been removed from this version. Also, some musical cues were changed such as when Samara leaps out of the well in the opening scene. The opening scene was also longer. The scene when the power went out was changed with a scene of the lights in Aidan's room going on and off, as well as the oven downstairs catching fire.

column4: title=The Ring Two – Box Office Data, DVD Sales, Movie News, Cast Information – The Numbers

column1: '''''The Ring Two''''' (stylized as '''''the ring twO''''') is a 2005 American [[supernatural]] [[psychological horror]] film and a [[sequel]] to the 2002 film ''[[The Ring (2002 film)
column2: The Ring]]'', which was a [[remake]] of the 1998 Japanese film ''[[Ring (film)
column3: Ringu]]''. [[Hideo Nakata]], director of the original Japanese film ''Ringu'', on which the American versions are based, directed this film in place of [[Gore Verbinski]].

column1: The film was shot in [[Astoria, Oregon]] and [[Los Angeles, California]]. It was released on March 18, 2005, and although it was met by generally negative critical reception, it opened in the United States with a strong [[US dollar
column2: US$]]35 million its first weekend, more than doubling the opening weekend of ''The Ring''. Its final $76 million domestic gross was less than the original's $129 million, but it took $85 million internationally, for a total gross of $161 million.

column1: It is the second installment in [[The Ring (franchise)
column2: ''The Ring'' film series]] and was followed by ''[[Rings (2017 film)

column1: Six months<!-- The short film ''Rings'' (2005) takes place in 2003 and this film is set in the same year, do not remove it --> after the events of the [[The Ring (2002 film)
column2: first film]] and following the events of the short film ''[[Rings (2005 film)
column3: Rings]]'', [[Samara Morgan]]’s cursed videotape has been circulating through teenagers in [[Astoria, Oregon]]. Jake Pierce is on his seventh day as per the tape's rules, and asks his friend Emily to watch the tape. He briefly steps into his kitchen while Emily supposedly watches the tape. Jake receives a phone call and initially thinks it is Samara but is relieved to realize it is only his friend with whom he had planned to trick Emily into watching the tape. Suddenly, Jake notices dark liquid pouring from under the kitchen door and runs outside to the living room, only to discover Emily closed her eyes while watching the tape. Jake is then promptly murdered by Samara.

column1: [[Rachel Keller]] and her son, Aidan, have moved to Astoria from [[Seattle]] after sending the tape off into the ether. Rachel works at ''[[The Daily Astorian]]'' for editor Max Rourke. Rachel learns of Jake's death, inspecting his body, only for Samara to appear, declaring that she has been looking for her. Rachel breaks into Jake's house, obtains the videotape and burns it. Aidan experiences a [[nightmare]] where Samara drags him into a television. He soon starts developing [[hypothermia]] and bruises on his arms. At a [[county fair]], Aidan wanders into a restroom and takes photographs of his reflection, where Samara appears. Rachel takes him home but they are attacked by multiple wild deer on the way. Rachel realizes Aidan may be possessed by Samara.
Max takes them in. While Rachel is attempting to give Aidan a bath, he develops an irrational [[Aquaphobia
column2: fear of water]]. Samara causes the water to recede from the bath, replacing Aidan with herself, and terrorizing Rachel so that she tries to drown Samara. Max enters, seeing her drowning Aidan instead, and forces her to take her son to the hospital. Based on Aidan's bruises, psychiatrist Emma Temple suspects [[child abuse]] on the part of Rachel, who admits she had [[postpartum depression]], and she sends Rachel away. Looking for answers, Rachel returns to the Morgan ranch on Moesko Island, finding evidence of Samara's biological mother Evelyn, who tried to drown her as an infant. Rachel visits Evelyn in a [[psychiatric hospital]], who advises her to \"listen to her baby\".

column1: In the hospital, Samara takes control of Aidan's body and [[Mind control in popular culture
column2: telepathically forces]] Dr. Temple to commit suicide before returning to Max's house. Max arrives, suspects foul play, and tries to secretly take photos of Aidan. Rachel arrives, discovering an affectionate Aidan waiting for her, but acting suspiciously out-of-character. She steps out, finding Max's corpse in his pickup truck. Rachel falls asleep, dreaming of Aidan, who tells her that she will have to [[exorcism
column3: exorcise]] Samara. Upon awakening, Rachel drugs Samara with sleeping pills and places her in the bath to temporarily drown Aidan in order to exorcise her. Samara is removed but appears in the television. Rachel allows herself to be dragged into Samara's monochromatic world.

column1: Finding herself in the bottom of the [[water well
column2: well]] Samara died in, Rachel discovers the lid is partially open. She scales the well's walls, pursued by Samara, but escapes by climbing out and pushing the lid shut on Samara, locking her out of her and Aidan's lives.

column1: Wandering through the woods, she comes to the cliff where Samara's adoptive mother Anna committed suicide. Hearing Aidan's voice, Rachel falls off the cliff and falls into the water, returning to the real world and reuniting with Aidan.
* [[Mary Elizabeth Winstead]] as Young Evelyn Borden

column1: '''Bob Currie''' (born Robert Frank Currie; 26 April 1918 in Woolwich, England – 25 July 1988 in Birmingham, England)<ref>[http://www.genesreunited.co.uk/search/results?sourcecategory=birthsutf002c%20marriages%20utf0026%20deaths&collection=births%20utf0026%20baptisms&datasetname=england%20utf0026%20wales%20births%201837-2006&firstname=robert&lastname=currie&birthyear=1918&birthyear_offset=0&keyword=woolwich England and Wales births] Retrieved 30 March 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.genesreunited.co.uk/search/results?sourcecategory=birthsutf002c%20marriages%20utf0026%20deaths&firstname=robert%20frank&lastname=currie&birthyear=1918&birthyear_offset=0&keyword=warwickshire&collection=deaths%2b%2526%2bburials England and Wales records] Retrieved 30 March 2016</ref> was an English motorcycling writer and road tester, who later became a magazine editor and book author. Mainly known for his UK journalism work with [[The Motor Cycle
column2: ''Motor Cycle'']], a UK weekly motorcycle magazine-turned-newspaper, then from 1981 as Editor of a new monthly magazine [[The Classic MotorCycle
column3: ''The Classic Motor Cycle'']], he retired in early 1988 suffering from an ongoing illness, after a full-time writing career starting in 1955, and later died of [[heart failure]].<ref name=\"Tribute \"/>

column1: Currie was described in 1967 by his editor as \"A prolific writer on all subjects\".<ref name=\"We're going bigger1\">[[The Motor Cycle
column2: ''Motor Cycle'']] 3 August 1967, p.1050. ''Meet our team. \"A prolific writer on all subjects\"''. Accessed 30 March 2016</ref> Writing in Currie's obituary, one former-collaborator remembered that many described him as \"The Walking Encyclopaedia of Motor Cycling History\", whilst his former understudy and editor-designate John Pearson described his death as \"this country has lost its leading writer, historian and authority on veteran, vintage and classic British motorcycles\".<ref name=\"Tribute \">Bob Currie Tribute by John Pearson, Editor, ''[[The Classic Motor Cycle]]'', September 1988, pp.8, 10-13. Accessed 30 March 2016</ref>

column1: With his younger brother, Ken, Currie spent his first few years with their father, an officer in the [[Royal Scots Greys]], at various postings. Soon after leaving the army in 1924 and settling at [[Martley]], [[Worcestershire]], their sister Daphne was born and Captain Currie died. Life for his widow with three children was difficult, and young Bob was sent to live with an aunt in [[Dundee]], later returning for his education at [[Worcester Royal Grammar School]] followed by work as a trainee engineer at [[Heenan & Froude]] in [[Worcester]] when he first started to ride motorcycles. He joined the [[Army Reserve (United Kingdom)
column3: conscription]] to the armed forces for the duration of [[World War II]], in the [[Royal Army Ordnance Corps
column4: RAOC]] (later known as [[Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers
column5: REME]]) where he maintained and repaired [[tank]]s and acted as a [[despatch rider]], progressing to the rank of [[Staff sergeant#United Kingdom

column1: After the end of hostilities, Currie returned to work for Heenan & Froude, also becoming involved with the [[The Automobile Association
column2: AA]] magazine, an occasional, [[newsletter]]-type publication mailed to members of the UK [[Subscription business model
column4: breakdown organisation]], and as a contributor to the ''TT Special'',<ref name=\"We're going bigger2\">[[The Motor Cycle
column5: ''Motor Cycle'']] 3 August 1967, p.1050. ''Meet our team. \"Before joining Motor Cycle was an assistant editor of the TT Special\"''. Accessed 30 March 2016</ref><ref>[[The Motor Cycle
column6: ''Motor Cycle'']] 28 October 1965, p.620. Accessed 30 March 2016</ref> a seasonal newspaper published by former TT rider Geoff Davison in June for the [[Isle of Man TT]] races, with occasional associated books.

column1: As a motorcycle enthusiast and seasonal reporter he travelled to the [[Isle of Man]]. When staying in the same [[Sefton Internment Camp
column2: Sefton Hotel]] as the [[The Motor Cycle
column3: ''Motor Cycle'']] staff he suggested a collaboration, to enable mutually-better reported coverage of the racing events.<ref name=\"Tribute \"/> Currie had previously submitted occasional articles to ''Motor Cycle'' magazine, and in 1955 a vacancy occurred when a regular staff-writer moved to a four-wheel magazine. Currie was offered the vacancy, initially at head office in London, progressing in 1956 to Midland Editor based at Birmingham, the area where his family resided, in a city central to a region where many British motorcycle manufacturers, metal-industries and component-producers were located.<ref name=\"Tribute\"/> When writing his serialised memoirs of 1969, former [[Motor Cycling (magazine)
column4: ''Motor Cycling'']] journalist Bruce Main-Smith stated he was offered the position of Midland Editor with then-rival publication ''[[The Motor Cycle]]'', but did not want to leave the London area and return to Birmingham where he was born, despite a generous offer of salary from then-Editor Harry Louis, a decision Main-Smith later regretted, and the job went to Currie.<ref>''Motorcycle Sport'', June 1969, pp.231-233. ''Motorcycling Moments, Part three: The Staff Job'', Accessed 30 March 2016</ref>

column1: Specialising in the traditional history of motorcycle manufacturing,  road-testing and technical articles, Currie established a strong rapport with the various manufacturers, often enjoying their trust in new developments which he kept confidential until the companies issued press releases.<ref name=\"Tribute\"/><ref name=\"We're going bigger4\">[[The Motor Cycle
column2: ''Motor Cycle'']] 3 August 1967, p.1050. ''Meet our team. \"Keeps up with the news from the factories\"''. Accessed 30 March 2016</ref> In 1965 Currie moved to an office suite at Lynton House, [[Birmingham]], where his desk was part of the parent-publisher's suite in a modern office tower block,<ref>[[The Motor Cycle
column3: Motor Cycle]], 25 November 1965. ''On the Four Winds by 'Nitor'.'' p.759. [image] \"''Bob Currie, our Midland Editor, is now comfortably ensconced in this new office block, Lynton House, Walsall Road, Birmingham. It houses all the staff of the International Publishing Corporation who work in the area.''\" Accessed 30 March 2016</ref> Currie was the last journalist on the staff of ''Motor Cycle'' to have a company motorcycle – he chose a [[Triumph Bonneville]].<ref name=\"Tribute \"/>

column1: In the 1970s, after a 10-year demise of British motorcycle manufacturing, Currie showed an increasing interest in the vintage and classic era, establishing a regular feature in ''Motor Cycle Weekly'' (as ''Motor Cycle'' was then known) named 'Past Times'. Motor Cycle had merged with Motor Cycling in 1967, so their combined archives were available to Currie.<ref name=\"Tribute \"/>

Publisher IPC decided the time was right to establish in 1981 a completely new magazine, ''[[The Classic Motor Cycle]]'', reminiscent of their early historic publication named ''[[The Motor Cycle]]'', to address the increasing public interest and popularity of classic motorcycles. Complete operational control was given to Currie in Birmingham, although overall responsibility remained at head-office in [[Sutton, London
column2: Sutton]], [[Surrey]], with former ''Motor Cycle Weekly'' editor Mick Woollett as Editor-in-Chief. In 1983, IPC sold ''The Classic Motor Cycle'' to [[EMAP]] along with the ''Motor Cycle'' and ''Motor Cycling'' archives, with Currie retained as editor based in Birmingham but with an assistant editor now at the Peterborough base of EMAP.<ref name=\"Tribute \"/>

column1: A bachelor, Currie played the [[banjolele]], harmonica and sang. He was an experienced [[Observed trials
column2: trials rider]] and also a keen local motorcycle-club enthusiast who gave slide shows and talks.<ref name=\"We're going bigger3\">[[The Motor Cycle
column3: ''Motor Cycle'']] 3 August 1967, p.1050. ''Meet our team. \"Trials rider for some years then became Midland Centre rally champion\"''. Accessed 30 March 2016</ref> As Vice-President of the [[Vintage Motor Cycle Club]] he judged [[concours d'elegance]] restorations, held Question-and-Answer sessions at classic bike shows and never tired of riding the many machines features in the magazine. Although most of his life was dedicated to motorcycles, he was also interested in [[steam power]] and [[traction engine]]s.<ref name=\"Tribute \"/>

column1: During the middle and later parts of his career Currie converted his vast experience of British manufacturers and period motorcycles into authorship of books, mostly in his own right but occasionally in collaboration with others.

Before his retirement planned for early 1988, he suffered from an illness involving incapacitation due to kidney problems. No longer able to type or write, he continued to edit using dictation – sometimes from his hospital bed – with assistance from his sister Daphne. Assistant-editor John Pearson continued to produce the magazine in close-collaboration. Later in the same year Currie died of [[heart failure]].<ref name=\"Tribute \"/>
* ''The Glory of the Manx TT 1907-1975''. 1976, [[New English Library]]
* ''Motor Cycling in the 1930s''. 1981, Littlehampton Book Services, {{ISBN
* ''Classic British Motorcycles - The Final Years''. 1984, Temple Press, {{ISBN
* ''The Art of Moto-Cross''. Bob Currie and Jeff Smith, 1967, [[Cassell (publisher)
* ''The Story of Triumph Motor Cycles''. Bob Currie and Harry Louis, 1978, Patrick Stephens, {{ISBN

column15: title=Definition for Scarborough - Oxford Dictionaries Online (World English)
column18: accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref> is a [[non-metropolitan district]] and [[borough]] of [[North Yorkshire]], [[England]].  In addition to the town of [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire
column19: Scarborough]], it covers a large stretch of the coast of Yorkshire, including [[Whitby]] and [[Filey]].<ref>{{cite news
column23: accessdate=15 September 2017}}</ref> It borders [[Redcar and Cleveland]] to the north, the [[Ryedale]] and [[Hambleton District
column24: Hambleton]] districts to the west and the [[East Riding of Yorkshire]] to the south.

column1: The district was formed on 1 April 1974, under the [[Local Government Act 1972]].  It was a merger of the [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)
column2: urban district]] of Filey and part of the [[Bridlington Rural District]], from the historic [[East Riding of Yorkshire]], along with the [[municipal borough]] of Scarborough, [[Scalby, North Yorkshire
column3: Scalby]] and Whitby [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)
column4: urban district]]s, and Scarborough Rural District and [[Whitby Rural District]], from the historic [[North Riding of Yorkshire

column1: In 2007, the borough was threatened with extinction.  In March of that year, [[North Yorkshire County Council]] was shortlisted by the [[Department for Communities and Local Government]] to be a unitary authority.  If the bid had been successful then the Borough of Scarborough would have—along with all other districts and boroughs in the present county of [[North Yorkshire]]—been abolished. The bid, however, was unsuccessful and the districts remain as they were previously constituted.
The political composition of the council since the [[2003 Scarborough Council election

column4: Labour]] !! [[UK Independence Party]] !! [[Green Party of England and Wales

column1: There are a total of 64 schools and colleges in the Scarborough area, as of 2012.
The Borough of Scarborough includes the villages of [[Allerston]], [[Crossgates, Scarborough

column15: title=Definition for Scarborough - Oxford Dictionaries Online (World English)
column18: accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref> is a [[non-metropolitan district]] and [[borough]] of [[North Yorkshire]], [[England]].  In addition to the town of [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire
column19: Scarborough]], it covers a large stretch of the coast of Yorkshire, including [[Whitby]] and [[Filey]].<ref>{{cite news
column23: accessdate=15 September 2017}}</ref> It borders [[Redcar and Cleveland]] to the north, the [[Ryedale]] and [[Hambleton District
column24: Hambleton]] districts to the west and the [[East Riding of Yorkshire]] to the south.

column1: The district was formed on 1 April 1974, under the [[Local Government Act 1972]].  It was a merger of the [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)
column2: urban district]] of Filey and part of the [[Bridlington Rural District]], from the historic [[East Riding of Yorkshire]], along with the [[municipal borough]] of Scarborough, [[Scalby, North Yorkshire
column3: Scalby]] and Whitby [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)
column4: urban district]]s, and Scarborough Rural District and [[Whitby Rural District]], from the historic [[North Riding of Yorkshire

column1: In 2007, the borough was threatened with extinction.  In March of that year, [[North Yorkshire County Council]] was shortlisted by the [[Department for Communities and Local Government]] to be a unitary authority.  If the bid had been successful then the Borough of Scarborough would have—along with all other districts and boroughs in the present county of [[North Yorkshire]]—been abolished. The bid, however, was unsuccessful and the districts remain as they were previously constituted.

column1: Customer service concerns the priority an organization assigns to customer service relative to components such as product innovation and pricing. In this sense, an organization that values good customer service may spend more money in training employees than the average organization or may proactively interview customers for feedback.

From the point of view of an overall [[sales process engineering]] effort, customer service plays an important role in an organization's ability to generate income and [[revenue]].<ref name=\"Selden1998\">{{cite journal
column4: title=''Sales Process Engineering: An Emerging Quality Application''
column6: pages = 59–63}}</ref> From that perspective, customer service should be included as part of an overall approach to systematic improvement. One good customer service experience can change the entire perception a customer holds towards the organization.<ref>Teresa Swartz, Dawn Iacobucci. ''Handbook of Services Marketing and Management''. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage</ref>

column1: A customer support is a range of customer services to assist customers in making cost effective and correct use of a product.<ref name=businessdictionary>[http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/customer-support.html businessdictionary.com > customer support] Retrieved March 2011</ref> It includes assistance in planning, installation, training, trouble shooting, maintenance, upgrading, and disposal of a product.<ref name=businessdictionary/> These services even may be done at customer's side where he/she uses the product or service. In this case it is called \"at home customer services\"'' or ''\"at home customer support.\"''
Regarding technology, products such as mobile phones, televisions, computers, software products or other electronic or mechanical goods, it is termed [[technical support]].
Customer service may be provided by a person (e.g., [[sales representative
column2: sales]] and service representative), or by automated means,{{Citation needed
column3: date=February 2015}} such as kiosks, [[Internet site]]s, and [[Application software
column4: apps]]. An advantage with automated means is an increased ability to provide service 24-hours a day, which can, at least, be a complement to customer service by persons.<ref name=Kongthon/>

column1: An increasingly popular type of automated customer service is conducted through [[artificial intelligence]] (\"AI\"). The customer benefit of AI is the feel for chatting with a live agent through improved speech technologies while giving customers the self-service benefit.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Google Duplex’s Conversational AI Shows a Path to Better Customer Service
column8: accessdate=2 June 2018}}</ref>  Another example of automated customer service is by [[push-button telephone
column9: touch-tone phone]], which usually involves IVR (Interactive Voice Response) a main menu and the use of the keypad as options (e.g., \"Press 1 for English, Press 2 for Spanish\", etc.){{cn

column1: However, in the [[Internet era]], a challenge has been to maintain and/or enhance the personal experience while making use of the efficiencies of [[online commerce]]. \"Online customers are literally invisible to you (and you to them), so it's easy to shortchange them emotionally. But this lack of visual and tactile presence makes it even more crucial to create a sense of personal, human-to-human connection in the online arena.\"<ref name=\"fast_comp_2010\">{{cite news
column3: title=Seven Keys to Building Customer Loyalty--and Company Profits

column5: avatar]] providing automated customer service on a web page.]]

column1: Examples of customer service by artificial means are [[automated online assistant]]s that can be seen as [[Avatar (computing)#Artificial intelligence
column2: avatars]] on websites,<ref name=Kongthon/> which enterprises can use to reduce their operating and training costs.<ref name=Kongthon/> These are driven by [[chatterbot]]s (also called \"chatbots\"), and a major underlying technology to such systems is [[natural language processing]].<ref name=Kongthon>{{cite news

column1: The two main ways of gathering feedback are: customer surveys and [[Net Promoter
column2: Net Promoter Score]] measurement, used for calculating the loyalty that exists between a provider and a consumer.{{citation needed

column1: Customer service metrics that are followed by companies depend on the tool used for customer service. Most popular metrics include:

column3: title=The Comprehensive Guide to Reducing Average Handle Time

column1: Many organizations have implemented feedback loops that allow them to capture feedback at the point of experience. For example, [[National Express]] in the UK has invited passengers to send text messages while  riding the bus. This has been shown to be useful, as it allows companies to improve their customer service before the customer defects, thus making it far more likely that the customer will return next time.<ref>{{cite news
column6: date=October 3, 2003}}</ref> Technology has made it increasingly easier for companies to obtain feedback from their customers. Community blogs and forums give customers the ability to give detailed explanations of both negative as well as positive experiences with a company/organization.

column1: There are few standards on this topic. [[International Organization for Standardization
column2: ISO]] and [[The International Customer Service Institute]] (TICSI) have published the following ones:

column1: * [[ISO 10002]]:2004, on quality management in handling customer complaints
* CCQA Customer Care Standard (Care Quality Alliance) www.CCQA.org.uk
There is also an [[Information Technology]] service management standard: [[ISO/IEC 20000
column2: ISO/IEC 20000:2005]]. Its first part concerns specifications and its second part the code of practice.

column11: postscript = .}}</ref> that the quality and level of customer service has decreased in recent years, and that this can be attributed to a lack of support or understanding at the executive and middle management levels of a corporation and/or a customer service policy. To address this argument, many organizations have employed a variety of methods to improve their customer satisfaction levels, and other [http://www.oracle.com/us/products/applications/cx-metrics-kpi-dictionary-1966465.pdf key performance indicators (KPIs)].<ref>{{Cite web

column2: ˈvɔjtɕɛx wɔbɔˈdʑij̃skʲi}}; born 20 October 1982 in [[Bydgoszcz]]), is a [[Poles
column3: Polish]] footballer who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Miedź Legnica]].

column1: Łobodziński started playing football with [[Zawisza Bydgoszcz]]. In 1999, he joined [[Stomil Olsztyn (football)
column2: Stomil Olsztyn]] where he made a debut in the [[Ekstraklasa]]. Subsequently, Łobodziński moved to [[Wisła Płock]] where he played until 2003. Then he played for [[Zagłębie Lubin]] and helped the team win Ekstraklasa championship in [[Ekstraklasa 2006–07
column3: 2006–07]] season. In 2008 Łobodziński moved to [[Wisła Kraków]] where he played until 2011, winning the Ekstraklasa title three times. In 2012, he joined another Ekstraklasa outfit, [[ŁKS Łódź]].

column1: He was part of the Polish U-16 team that placed second at the [[UEFA U-16 Championship]] in 1999 as well as the U-18 team that won the [[UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship
column2: UEFA U-18 Championship]] in 2001. On 6 December 2006, he made his debut for the [[Poland national football team
column3: senior side]] of his country in the 5:2 victory against [[United Arab Emirates national football team
column4: United Arab Emirates]] in a [[friendly match]]. Łobodziński was selected for the Polish [[UEFA Euro 2008
column5: Euro 2008]] squad, appearing in all three group stage matches in an eventual group stage exit.

column1: On 11 January 2019 it was announced, that Łobodziński would retire from professional football and instead continue playing for the reserve team of [[Miedź Legnica]] where he also was supposed to function as the assistant manager.<ref>[http://www.90minut.pl/news/292/news2927257-Wojciech-Lobodzinski-asystentem-trenera-rezerw-Miedzi.html Wojciech Łobodziński asystentem trenera rezerw Miedzi], 90minut.pl, 11 January 2019</ref>
