'''''The Origin of Capitalism''''' is a 1999 book on [[history]] and [[political economy]], specifically the [[history of capitalism]], by scholar [[Ellen Meiksins Wood]], written from the perspective of [[Political Marxism]]. It was reviewed as an \"Outstanding Academic Book\" by [[Michael Perelman (economist)
The book is divided into three sections. The following summary is based on the second edition (though some references are to the first).

Wood's [[Marxist]] approach originates from [[Karl Marx]]'s critique of [[political economy]] in his works ''[[Das Kapital]]'' and ''[[Grundrisse]]''.<ref>1999, p. 35.</ref> In the capitalist form of society, human [[labor power]] is for sale in the market as one of many commodities.<ref name=\"1999, p. 2\">1999, p. 2.</ref> Goods and services, including those regarding the most basic necessities of life, are produced for profitable exchange.<ref name=\"1999, p. 2\"/> All the actors in a such system are driven by [[competition]] and [[profit (economics)
column2: profit]]-maximization.<ref name=\"1999, p. 2\"/> However, the study presents capitalists' appropriation of \"workers' surplus labor without coercion\"<ref name=\"1999, p. 70\">1999, p. 70.</ref> by using the market to set rates of compensation both for wages and for appropriation<ref name=\"1999, p. 70\"/> as the most distinctive and historically important feature of capitalism. Thus it argues that the origin of capitalism lies fundamentally in social property relations rather than in trade and commerce.

column1: Wood argues that past historians have tended to see capitalism as a natural and even inevitable human behaviour, which came into being when barriers to trade and commerce were removed: essentially, in their understanding, people were waiting for the ''opportunity'' to become capitalists. Wood argues rather that capitalism did not come about until a set of unique historical circumstances ''compelled'' people to.

In Part I, Wood surveys past work on the transition to capitalism. She sketches how [[Adam Smith]], [[Max Weber]], [[Fernand Braudel]], and [[Henri Pirenne]] assumed that capitalism naturally arises from trade, commerce, and urbanisation once city-dwellers have accumulated enough [[primitive capital]] to be able to reinvest it in production. However, she also finds that even commentators who were critical of this account tend to argue that the transition to capitalism entailed farmers seizing new opportunities to switch from subsistence to commodity production as the constraints of [[feudalism]] were loosened. Examples include [[Karl Marx]] himself, [[Karl Polanyi]], [[Paul Sweezy]], [[Maurice Dobb]], [[Rodney Hilton]], and [[Perry Anderson]]. This suggests that capitalism is a natural and inevitable behaviour, waiting for its opportunity, rather than historically unusual and specific. Building particularly on the arguments made in the [[Brenner Debate]] and on the work of [[E. P. Thompson]], Wood argues that 'we need a form of history that brings this specificity into sharp relief'.<ref>2002, p. 69.</ref>

In Part II, Wood argues that capitalism emerged in the unique conditions of late medieval and early modern English agrarian society, basing her argument firmly on Robert Brenner's ‘Agrarian Class Structure and Economic Development in Pre-Industrial Europe’.<ref>Brenner, Robert (1976). ‘Agrarian Class Structure and Economic Development in Pre-Industrial Europe,’ ''Past & Present'', 70, February, pp. 30-75.</ref> She argues that commerce is not equivalent to capitalism and does not produce it because 'the dominant principle of trade everywhere was not surplus value derived from production but \"profit on alienation\", \"buying cheap and selling dear\" ':<ref>2002, p. 78.</ref> that is, although trade involves the seeking of profits, it does not in itself affect how goods are produced. Wood argues that polities which flourished from trade such as medieval [[Florence]] and the early-modern [[Dutch Republic]] that did not become capitalist are not examples of a 'failed transition', but rather examples of how trade and urbanisation has flourished widely in human history without capitalism developing. She likewise argues that various past societies, such as early modern France, had peasantries with ample opportunity to enter into commercial production, which, however, did not take this opportunity. Thus Wood concludes that capitalism must have arisen from changing ''imperatives'' in fundamental relations of ''production''.<ref name=\"Perelman\">Perelman, Oct. 1999</ref>
Wood sees these unique circumstances arising in [[Economy of England in the Middle Ages
column2: late medieval]] and early-modern England (particularly the south-east). In the wake of the [[Norman Conquest]], the English state was unusually centralised. This gave aristocrats relatively limited powers to extract wealth directly from their feudal underlings through political means (not least the threat of violence). England's centralisation also meant that an unusual number of English farmers were not peasants (with their own land and thus direct access to subsistence) but [[Tenant farmer
column3: tenants]] (renting their land). These circumstances produced a market in leases. Landlords, lacking other ways to extract wealth, were incentivised to rent to those tenants who could pay the most, while tenants, lacking security of tenure, were incentivised to farm as productively as possible to be able to win leases in a competitive market. This led to a cascade of effects whereby successful tenant farmers became agrarian capitalists; unsuccessful ones became wage-labourers, required to sell their labour in order to live; and landlords promoted the privatisation and renting out of common land, not least through the [[enclosures]].<ref name=obit>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/feb/10/ellen-meiksins-wood-obituary  David McNally, \"Ellen Meiksins Wood obituary\" ''The Guardian''].</ref> 'It was not merchants or manufacturers who drove the process that propelled the early development of capitalism. The transformation of social property relations was firmly rooted in the countryside, and the transformation of England's trade and industry was result more than cause of England's transition to capitalism'.<ref>2002, p. 129.</ref>

column1: In Part III, Wood sketches how industrial capitalism developed from its agrarian English origins. She argues that the end of subsistence farming produced a large population which needed both to sell its labour and to buy basic necessities of life, creating a mass consumer market quite different from the markets for luxury goods that characterised non-capitalist commerce. This mass market underpinned the development of mass production.

Wood argues that England's rising productivity slowly but inevitably forced competing economies to enter capitalist modes of production: although the development of capitalism was a chance event, it set in motion a transition that would become global. She argues that English capitalism did not cause England's imperialism, noting that neighbouring non-capitalist economies like Spain and France also built overseas empires. She does find, however, that English capitalism produced a distinctive kind of imperialism. Rather than ruling purely through 'extra-economic' methods of exerting power (such as force), England exported its model of social property relations to its colonies, providing powerful economic imperatives for people to adopt capitalism. English imperialism also drew on the nascent capitalist ideology of thinkers such as [[Thomas More]], [[Sir John Davies]], [[John Locke]], and [[William Petty]] to justify taking the land of peoples who were thought not to be making sufficiently productive use of it.

Wood sketches the reliance of capitalism on the political structures of the [[nation-state]] (particularly its protection of private property), and emphasises that the humane and universalist ideas of the [[Age of Enlightenment
column2: Enlightenment]] emerged in the still non-capitalist France of the eighteenth century, setting Enlightenment ideas in contrast to capitalist ideologies. Finally, she emphasises that if capitalism is a historically specific and unusual development, it is not inevitable or the only way that humans might organise themselves.

column1: The book was originally published in 1999 by [[Monthly Review]] Press, and then a revised<ref>According to the Acknowledgements, the second edition is \"...substantially revised and expanded...\"</ref> edition was published in 2002 by [[Verso Books]], with the subtitle \"A Longer View\".<ref>Copyright notice on the 2002 edition</ref> A reprint appeared in 2013 and again in 2017.

column2: Wood, Ellen Meiksins]] (1999) ''The Origin of Capitalism'', [[Monthly Review]] Press, 1999. {{ISBN

column2: Michael Perelman]]'s review [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZexwH4DF8gEC&pg=PA385&lpg=PA385&dq=1-58367-000-9&source=web&ots=ghBTeX76B7&sig=qjiprjhi7KWnjxlh_cUJkE_-k_A&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result] published in ''[[Choice: Current Reviews for Academic Libraries]]'', ( sections: Social & Behavioral Sciences \\ Economics ) October 1999, n. 37

column1: * Review in ''The Economic Journal'' [https://archive.today/20121002165855/http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119060739/abstract Volume 109 Issue 459], Pages 867 - 876 Published Online: 28 Jun 2008

'''''The Origin of Capitalism''''' is a 1999 book on [[history]] and [[political economy]], specifically the [[history of capitalism]], by scholar [[Ellen Meiksins Wood]], written from the perspective of [[Political Marxism]]. It was reviewed as an \"Outstanding Academic Book\" by [[Michael Perelman (economist)
The book is divided into three sections. The following summary is based on the second edition (though some references are to the first).

Wood's [[Marxist]] approach originates from [[Karl Marx]]'s critique of [[political economy]] in his works ''[[Das Kapital]]'' and ''[[Grundrisse]]''.<ref>1999, p. 35.</ref> In the capitalist form of society, human [[labor power]] is for sale in the market as one of many commodities.<ref name=\"1999, p. 2\">1999, p. 2.</ref> Goods and services, including those regarding the most basic necessities of life, are produced for profitable exchange.<ref name=\"1999, p. 2\"/> All the actors in a such system are driven by [[competition]] and [[profit (economics)
column2: profit]]-maximization.<ref name=\"1999, p. 2\"/> However, the study presents capitalists' appropriation of \"workers' surplus labor without coercion\"<ref name=\"1999, p. 70\">1999, p. 70.</ref> by using the market to set rates of compensation both for wages and for appropriation<ref name=\"1999, p. 70\"/> as the most distinctive and historically important feature of capitalism. Thus it argues that the origin of capitalism lies fundamentally in social property relations rather than in trade and commerce.

column1: Wood argues that past historians have tended to see capitalism as a natural and even inevitable human behaviour, which came into being when barriers to trade and commerce were removed: essentially, in their understanding, people were waiting for the ''opportunity'' to become capitalists. Wood argues rather that capitalism did not come about until a set of unique historical circumstances ''compelled'' people to.

In Part I, Wood surveys past work on the transition to capitalism. She sketches how [[Adam Smith]], [[Max Weber]], [[Fernand Braudel]], and [[Henri Pirenne]] assumed that capitalism naturally arises from trade, commerce, and urbanisation once city-dwellers have accumulated enough [[primitive capital]] to be able to reinvest it in production. However, she also finds that even commentators who were critical of this account tend to argue that the transition to capitalism entailed farmers seizing new opportunities to switch from subsistence to commodity production as the constraints of [[feudalism]] were loosened. Examples include [[Karl Marx]] himself, [[Karl Polanyi]], [[Paul Sweezy]], [[Maurice Dobb]], [[Rodney Hilton]], and [[Perry Anderson]]. This suggests that capitalism is a natural and inevitable behaviour, waiting for its opportunity, rather than historically unusual and specific. Building particularly on the arguments made in the [[Brenner Debate]] and on the work of [[E. P. Thompson]], Wood argues that 'we need a form of history that brings this specificity into sharp relief'.<ref>2002, p. 69.</ref>

In Part II, Wood argues that capitalism emerged in the unique conditions of late medieval and early modern English agrarian society, basing her argument firmly on Robert Brenner's ‘Agrarian Class Structure and Economic Development in Pre-Industrial Europe’.<ref>Brenner, Robert (1976). ‘Agrarian Class Structure and Economic Development in Pre-Industrial Europe,’ ''Past & Present'', 70, February, pp. 30-75.</ref> She argues that commerce is not equivalent to capitalism and does not produce it because 'the dominant principle of trade everywhere was not surplus value derived from production but \"profit on alienation\", \"buying cheap and selling dear\" ':<ref>2002, p. 78.</ref> that is, although trade involves the seeking of profits, it does not in itself affect how goods are produced. Wood argues that polities which flourished from trade such as medieval [[Florence]] and the early-modern [[Dutch Republic]] that did not become capitalist are not examples of a 'failed transition', but rather examples of how trade and urbanisation has flourished widely in human history without capitalism developing. She likewise argues that various past societies, such as early modern France, had peasantries with ample opportunity to enter into commercial production, which, however, did not take this opportunity. Thus Wood concludes that capitalism must have arisen from changing ''imperatives'' in fundamental relations of ''production''.<ref name=\"Perelman\">Perelman, Oct. 1999</ref>
Wood sees these unique circumstances arising in [[Economy of England in the Middle Ages
column2: late medieval]] and early-modern England (particularly the south-east). In the wake of the [[Norman Conquest]], the English state was unusually centralised. This gave aristocrats relatively limited powers to extract wealth directly from their feudal underlings through political means (not least the threat of violence). England's centralisation also meant that an unusual number of English farmers were not peasants (with their own land and thus direct access to subsistence) but [[Tenant farmer
column3: tenants]] (renting their land). These circumstances produced a market in leases. Landlords, lacking other ways to extract wealth, were incentivised to rent to those tenants who could pay the most, while tenants, lacking security of tenure, were incentivised to farm as productively as possible to be able to win leases in a competitive market. This led to a cascade of effects whereby successful tenant farmers became agrarian capitalists; unsuccessful ones became wage-labourers, required to sell their labour in order to live; and landlords promoted the privatisation and renting out of common land, not least through the [[enclosures]].<ref name=obit>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/feb/10/ellen-meiksins-wood-obituary  David McNally, \"Ellen Meiksins Wood obituary\" ''The Guardian''].</ref> 'It was not merchants or manufacturers who drove the process that propelled the early development of capitalism. The transformation of social property relations was firmly rooted in the countryside, and the transformation of England's trade and industry was result more than cause of England's transition to capitalism'.<ref>2002, p. 129.</ref>

column1: In Part III, Wood sketches how industrial capitalism developed from its agrarian English origins. She argues that the end of subsistence farming produced a large population which needed both to sell its labour and to buy basic necessities of life, creating a mass consumer market quite different from the markets for luxury goods that characterised non-capitalist commerce. This mass market underpinned the development of mass production.

Wood argues that England's rising productivity slowly but inevitably forced competing economies to enter capitalist modes of production: although the development of capitalism was a chance event, it set in motion a transition that would become global. She argues that English capitalism did not cause England's imperialism, noting that neighbouring non-capitalist economies like Spain and France also built overseas empires. She does find, however, that English capitalism produced a distinctive kind of imperialism. Rather than ruling purely through 'extra-economic' methods of exerting power (such as force), England exported its model of social property relations to its colonies, providing powerful economic imperatives for people to adopt capitalism. English imperialism also drew on the nascent capitalist ideology of thinkers such as [[Thomas More]], [[Sir John Davies]], [[John Locke]], and [[William Petty]] to justify taking the land of peoples who were thought not to be making sufficiently productive use of it.

Wood sketches the reliance of capitalism on the political structures of the [[nation-state]] (particularly its protection of private property), and emphasises that the humane and universalist ideas of the [[Age of Enlightenment
column2: Enlightenment]] emerged in the still non-capitalist France of the eighteenth century, setting Enlightenment ideas in contrast to capitalist ideologies. Finally, she emphasises that if capitalism is a historically specific and unusual development, it is not inevitable or the only way that humans might organise themselves.

column1: The book was originally published in 1999 by [[Monthly Review]] Press, and then a revised<ref>According to the Acknowledgements, the second edition is \"...substantially revised and expanded...\"</ref> edition was published in 2002 by [[Verso Books]], with the subtitle \"A Longer View\".<ref>Copyright notice on the 2002 edition</ref> A reprint appeared in 2013.

column4: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]]

column2: MC]] (1889-1964) was a British soldier and priest.  He served as an Officer in the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] during [[World War I]] for which he was [[mentioned in despatches]], awarded a [[Military Cross]] and the [[Croix de Guerre]], as Captain and subsequently Major of his Regiment.<ref name=\"auto6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Life story: Arthur Raley | Lives of the First World War
column7: title=Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador, volume 2 [Extract: letter Hac-Hoy] :: Encyclopedia of Newfoundland and Labrador
column13: title=A History of the Church Lads' Brigade in Newfoundland
column18: via=Google Books}}</ref>  After the [[World War I
column19: War]] he was ordained and later became [[Military chaplain
column21: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he had the relative rank of Squadron Leader and was again [[mentioned in despatches]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref name=\"auto\">https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_arthur_0-149_0.pdf</ref><ref name=\"auto4\">https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/34636/page/4049/data.pdf</ref>  Prior to [[World War I]], Raley worked on the [[Grenfell Mission]] in [[Labrador]], [[Canada]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

column1: Arthur Raley was born at [[Barnsley]], [[England]] in 1889.<ref name=\"auto5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  He was educated at [[Bedford Modern School]] where, as an accomplished cricketer, he was in the first XI in 1905 and 1906.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Community: Bedford Modern School - Eagle Magazine extracts | Lives of the First World War
column11: website=livesofthefirstworldwar.iwm.org.uk}}</ref>  He played in a cricket match with [[W. G. Grace]] shortly after leaving school.<ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref>http://www.hemsworthgrammarschool.org/Downloadable%20Files/School%20History%201932a.pdf</ref>

column1: After school, Raley trained as a surveyor but gave it up and emigrated to [[Newfoundland]], [[Canada]], on his 21st birthday with the ultimate aim of being ordained.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He initially worked as a schoolmaster at what is now [[Bishop Feild College]] in [[Newfoundland]] before joining the [[Grenfell Mission]] and being sent to northern [[Labrador]] where he took command of a reindeer ranch organising medical supplies and assistance to remote communities.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

Raley joined the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] but when [[World War I]] was declared, he signed up with the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] as a Lieutenant on 24 September 1914.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Lieutenant Owen William Steele of the Newfoundland Regiment
column8: via=Google Books}}</ref>  As part of the [[Mediterranean Expeditionary Force]] he saw action in [[Gallipoli]], having landed at [[Suvla Bay]], and was promoted Captain on 28 July 1915 and Adjutant on 29 September 1915.<ref name=\"auto5\"/><ref name=\"auto7\"/><ref>{{Cite web

column1: Raley was admitted to hospital in [[Malta]] on 13 December 1915 but rejoined the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment
column2: Regiment]] at [[Suez]] on 31 January 1916.<ref name=\"auto7\"/>  His Regiment was part of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)
column3: British Expeditionary Force]] on 14 March 1916 and Raley was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 1 January 1917.<ref name=\"auto7\"/><ref name=\"auto1\"/>  The citation for his [[Military Cross]] read:<ref>https://www.therooms.ca/sites/default/files/raley_0-149.pdf</ref><ref name=\"auto1\"/>

column1: For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.  He organised and gallantly led a bombing attack driving the enemy back at a critical time.  He set a splendid example of courage and initiative.
Raley was wounded at [[Monchy-le-Preux]] during the [[Battle of Arras (1917)
column2: Battle of Arras]] in April 1917 after which he returned to [[England]] to convalesce.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs
column9: via=Google Books}}</ref>  On 23 May 1917, he was attached to the Depot, Ayr, and rejoined his Regiment on 26 January 1918.

column4: Capt. A Raley (left) and Lt Col A.E. Bernard leading the Royal Newfoundland Regiment across the Rhine, 1918]]

column1: Following the Armistice, Captain Raley and Lt. Col. A.E. Bernard led the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] across the Rhine into Germany on 13 December 1918.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=www.heritage.nf.ca}}</ref>  He was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] in 1919.<ref>https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/31409/supplement/7805/data.pdf</ref>  He was appointed Second in Command of the 1st Battalion of his Regiment in May 1919 before his return to Newfoundland.<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web
column6: title=The Canadian Experience of the Great War: A Guide to Memoirs

column1: According to ''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]]'', Raley returned to England and entered Theological College after which he was made Deacon of the Church of All Saints Luton where he became a Priest in 1924.<ref name=\"auto3\">{{Cite web
column6: via=Google Books}}</ref>  For the next fifteen years he worked as a parish priest at Christ Church Luton and as Vicar of Grimethorpe (1931-49).<ref name=\"auto2\"/><ref name=\"auto3\"/><ref name=\"auto3\"/><ref name=\"auto2\"/><ref>https://www.barnsleybenefice.org/content/pages/documents/1461176117.pdf</ref>

column3: Royal Air Force Command]] during [[World War II]] where he was again [[mentioned in despatches]] and had the relative rank of Squadron Leader.<ref name=\"auto4\"/><ref name=\"auto\"/>  He left his Vicarship at Grimethorpe in 1949,<ref>The London Gazette, 8 March 1949, p.1203</ref> but remained Vicar of St Edward’s Church Barnsley until 1961.<ref name=\"auto3\"/>

column1: In 1960, Raley was honoured by his old school, being made President of the [[Bedford Modern School
column2: Old Bedford Modernians’ Club]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/>  He died in [[Bedford]] in 1964.<ref name=\"auto6\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column6: publisher=National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

Terence Blackers career is now mainly focused on songwriting. He has releases a number of albums recently and performed at festivals across the UK. Separately, he is not a publisher now - though he was around 30 years ago. Lastly he has never been a journalist - he was and is a columnist but was never a journalist.,safe,Bobby Ferew,"{{Use British English
'''Terence Blacker''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature
column2: FRSL]] (born 5 February 1948, near [[Hadleigh, Suffolk]]) is an English songwriter, author and columnist.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Open Directory – Arts: Literature: Authors: B: Blacker,_Terence

column1: Blacker is the son of General Sir [[Cecil Hugh Blacker]], and the brother of [[sculpture
column2: sculptor]] and former jockey [[Philip Blacker]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: date=February 2013}}<!--Lundy is not a reliable source so cite Lundy's reliable source See [[WP:SAYWHEREYOUREADIT]]--></ref>

column1: He grew up on the family farm in Suffolk. He attended [[Hawtreys]] preparatory school and [[Wellington College, Berkshire
column2: Wellington College]] before reading English at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], whence he graduated in 1969.

column1: Blacker began his working life in horse-racing and as an amateur jockey.<ref name=writers_online>

column11: url-status=dead }}</ref> Subsequently, he worked in publishing for 10 years during the 1970s and 1980s,<ref name=writers_online /> where he was responsible for overseeing the publication of works by [[Jerzy Kosinski]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Plagiarism? Let's just call it postmodernism

column1: Blacker became a full-time writer in 1983 and has written children's books and mysteries for adults. His first children's book ''If I Could Work'' was published in 1987 and his first adult novel, ''FIXX'', won critical acclaim and was described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as a \"tour de force\". He is an active member of English PEN, and is also an [[East Anglian Writers

In 1975 he married Caroline Soper, youngest daughter of the radical Methodist minister [[Donald Soper]] (div. 2001). They have two children Xan and Alice. Blacker's partner is now Angela Sykes.<ref>{{cite web
He writes the \"Endpaper\" for ''The Author''. For many years, he wrote the \"Harvey Porlock\" column in ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)
column2: The Sunday Times]]'', as well as a column about the book business for ''Publishing News''.<ref name=writers_online />

column1: His regular writing for ''[[The Independent]]'', newspaper, usually consisting of twice-weekly columns, came to an end in December 2013 after nearly 16 years.<ref>Terence Blacker, [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/by-all-means-prepare-for-old-age-but-dont-forget-to-live-in-the-present-9008608.html \"By all means ‘prepare’ for old age. But don’t forget to live in the present\"], ''The Independent'', 16 December 2013.</ref>

Blacker was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature]] in 2017.<ref>Onwuemezi, Natasha, [http://www.thebookseller.com/news/syal-and-mcdermid-named-new-rsl-fellows-564396 \"Rankin, McDermid and Levy named new RSL fellows\"], ''[[The Bookseller]]'', 7 June 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web
**''You Cannot Live as I Have Lived and Not End Up Like This: The Thoroughly Disgraceful Life and Times of Willie Donaldson'' (Ebury Press, 2007) {{ISBN
**''The Surprising Adventures of Baron Munchausen'' (Hodder Children's Books, 1990) {{ISBN
**''Herbie Hamster, Where Are You?'' by Terence Blacker, [[Pippa Unwin]] (Random House Children's Books, 1990) {{ISBN
**''Neil's Book of the Dead'' by Terence Blacker, [[Nigel Planer]] (Pavilion Books, 1984) {{ISBN
**''Out of Control, Ms Wiz'' (Macmillan Children's Books, 2009) {{ISBN
**''The Crazy World of Ms Wiz'' (Macmillan Children's Books, 2004) {{ISBN

**''Ms Wiz Goes to Hollywood'' (Macmillan Children's Books, 2000) {{ISBN

'''Terence Blacker''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature
column2: FRSL]] (born 5 February 1948, near [[Hadleigh, Suffolk]]) is an English author, columnist, journalist, and publisher.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Open Directory – Arts: Literature: Authors: B: Blacker,_Terence

column1: Blacker is the son of General Sir [[Cecil Hugh Blacker]], and the brother of [[sculpture
column2: sculptor]] and former jockey [[Philip Blacker]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: date=February 2013}}<!--Lundy is not a reliable source so cite Lundy's reliable source See [[WP:SAYWHEREYOUREADIT]]--></ref>

column1: He grew up on the family farm in Suffolk. He attended [[Hawtreys]] preparatory school and [[Wellington College, Berkshire
column2: Wellington College]] before reading English at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], whence he graduated in 1969.

column1: Blacker began his working life in horse-racing and as an amateur jockey.<ref name=writers_online>

column11: url-status=dead }}</ref> Subsequently, he worked in publishing for 10 years during the 1970s and 1980s,<ref name=writers_online /> where he was responsible for overseeing the publication of works by [[Jerzy Kosinski]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Plagiarism? Let's just call it postmodernism

column1: Blacker became a full-time writer in 1983 and has written children's books and mysteries for adults. His first children's book ''If I Could Work'' was published in 1987 and his first adult novel, ''FIXX'', won critical acclaim and was described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as a \"tour de force\". He is an active member of English PEN, and is also an [[East Anglian Writers

In 1975 he married Caroline Soper, youngest daughter of the radical Methodist minister [[Donald Soper]] (div. 2001). They have two children Xan and Alice. Blacker's partner is now Angela Sykes.<ref>{{cite web
He writes the \"Endpaper\" for ''The Author''. For many years, he wrote the \"Harvey Porlock\" column in ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)
column2: The Sunday Times]]'', as well as a column about the book business for ''Publishing News''.<ref name=writers_online />

column1: His regular writing for ''[[The Independent]]'', newspaper, usually consisting of twice-weekly columns, came to an end in December 2013 after nearly 16 years.<ref>Terence Blacker, [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/by-all-means-prepare-for-old-age-but-dont-forget-to-live-in-the-present-9008608.html \"By all means ‘prepare’ for old age. But don’t forget to live in the present\"], ''The Independent'', 16 December 2013.</ref>

Blacker was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature]] in 2017.<ref>Onwuemezi, Natasha, [http://www.thebookseller.com/news/syal-and-mcdermid-named-new-rsl-fellows-564396 \"Rankin, McDermid and Levy named new RSL fellows\"], ''[[The Bookseller]]'', 7 June 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web
